events.title: Examination of Billy Bones's Account Book
detailed_summary: The doctor used his medical scissors from his instrument case to cut the stitches securing the bundle.
Inside, they found two items: a book and a sealed paper.
Dr. Livesey decided they would examine the book first.
The squire and Jim peered over the doctor's shoulder as he opened it, Jim having been invited by the doctor to join them from his meal to observe the investigation.

The first page contained miscellaneous scribbles, like those made idly: 'Billy Bones his fancy,' 'Mr. W. Bones, mate,' 'No more rum,' 'Off Palm Key he got itt,' and other mostly unintelligible fragments.
Jim found himself wondering about the person who 'got itt' and what 'itt' referred to, speculating it might have been a fatal injury.
Dr. Livesey commented that these initial writings offered little useful information and moved on.

The subsequent ten to twelve pages were filled with peculiar entries: dates on one side and sums of money on the other, similar to an account book, but with varying numbers of crosses instead of written explanations.
An example from June 12th, 1745, showed seventy pounds due, with only six crosses as explanation.
A few entries included place names like 'Offe Caraccas' or geographical coordinates.

The accounts spanned almost twenty years, with the recorded sums growing larger over time, culminating in a grand total labeled 'Bones, his pile,' which was reached after several incorrect calculations.
Dr. Livesey confessed he could not understand the meaning of the entries.
The squire, however, declared it perfectly clear, identifying it as the pirate's account book where crosses denoted sunk or plundered ships or towns.
He interpreted the sums as the pirate's share of the loot, with clearer notations like 'Offe Caraccas' added when there might be ambiguity about a plundered vessel, lamenting the fate of its crew.

Dr. Livesey agreed with the squire's interpretation, acknowledging the value of travel experience in deciphering such matters, and also noted how the sums increased as Bones presumably advanced in his piratical career.

The bundle was sewn together, and the doctor had to get out his instrument case and cut the stitches with his medical scissors. It contained two things—a book and a sealed paper.
“First of all we’ll try the book,” observed the doctor.
The squire and I were both peering over his shoulder as he opened it, for Dr. Livesey had kindly motioned me to come round from the side-table, where I had been eating, to enjoy the sport of the search. On the first page there were only some scraps of writing, such as a man with a pen in his hand might make for idleness or practice. One was the same as the tattoo mark, “Billy Bones his fancy”; then there was “Mr. W. Bones, mate,” “No more rum,” “Off Palm Key he got itt,” and some other snatches, mostly single words and unintelligible. I could not help wondering who it was that had “got itt,” and what “itt” was that he got. A knife in his back as like as not.
“Not much instruction there,” said Dr. Livesey as he passed on.
The next ten or twelve pages were filled with a curious series of entries. There was a date at one end of the line and at the other a sum of money, as in common account-books, but instead of explanatory writing, only a varying number of crosses between the two. On the 12th of June, 1745, for instance, a sum of seventy pounds had plainly become due to someone, and there was nothing but six crosses to explain the cause. In a few cases, to be sure, the name of a place would be added, as “Offe Caraccas,” or a mere entry of latitude and longitude, as “62° 17′ 20″, 19° 2′ 40″.”
The record lasted over nearly twenty years, the amount of the separate entries growing larger as time went on, and at the end a grand total had been made out after five or six wrong additions, and these words appended, “Bones, his pile.”
“I can’t make head or tail of this,” said Dr. Livesey.
“The thing is as clear as noonday,” cried the squire. “This is the black-hearted hound’s account-book. These crosses stand for the names of ships or towns that they sank or plundered. The sums are the scoundrel’s share, and where he feared an ambiguity, you see he added something clearer. ‘Offe Caraccas,’ now; you see, here was some unhappy vessel boarded off that coast. God help the poor souls that manned her—coral long ago.”
“Right!” said the doctor. “See what it is to be a traveller. Right! And the amounts increase, you see, as he rose in rank.”

Next to the southwestern cross, written in the same red ink but in a small, neat handwriting distinct from the captain's unsteady script, were the words: 'Bulk of treasure here.'

On the reverse side of the map, the same neat handwriting provided further instructions: 'Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.'

Additional directions indicated that bar silver was located in a 'north cache,' discoverable by following the trend of an eastern hummock, ten fathoms south of a black crag with a facial feature. Arms were to be found in a sand-hill at the north point of a north inlet cape, bearing E. and a quarter N., initialed 'J.F.'
Although these concise instructions were baffling to Jim, they brought immense joy to both the squire and Dr. Livesey.

There was little else in the volume but a few bearings of places noted in the blank leaves towards the end and a table for reducing French, English, and Spanish moneys to a common value.
“Thrifty man!” cried the doctor. “He wasn’t the one to be cheated.”
“And now,” said the squire, “for the other.”
The paper had been sealed in several places with a thimble by way of seal; the very thimble, perhaps, that I had found in the captain’s pocket. The doctor opened the seals with great care, and there fell out the map of an island, with latitude and longitude, soundings, names of hills and bays and inlets, and every particular that would be needed to bring a ship to a safe anchorage upon its shores. It was about nine miles long and five across, shaped, you might say, like a fat dragon standing up, and had two fine land-locked harbours, and a hill in the centre part marked “The Spy-glass.” There were several additions of a later date, but above all, three crosses of red ink—two on the north part of the island, one in the southwest—and beside this last, in the same red ink, and in a small, neat hand, very different from the captain’s tottery characters, these words: “Bulk of treasure here.”
Over on the back the same hand had written this further information: Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet. The bar silver is in the north cache; you can find it by the trend of the east hummock, ten fathoms south of the black crag with the face on it. The arms are easy found, in the sand-hill, N. point of north inlet cape, bearing E. and a quarter N. J.F.
That was all; but brief as it was, and to me incomprehensible, it filled the squire and Dr. Livesey with delight.

Dr. Livesey advised extreme caution: no member of their party should travel alone until they were safely at sea. He proposed that he and Jim would remain together, while the squire should take Joyce and Hunter with him to Bristol.
Crucially, he insisted that none of them should utter a single word about their discovery.
The squire acknowledged the wisdom of Dr. Livesey's counsel and promised to maintain complete secrecy.

“Livesey,” said the squire, “you will give up this wretched practice at once. Tomorrow I start for Bristol. In three weeks’ time—three weeks!—two weeks—ten days—we’ll have the best ship, sir, and the choicest crew in England. Hawkins shall come as cabin-boy. You’ll make a famous cabin-boy, Hawkins. You, Livesey, are ship’s doctor; I am admiral. We’ll take Redruth, Joyce, and Hunter. We’ll have favourable winds, a quick passage, and not the least difficulty in finding the spot, and money to eat, to roll in, to play duck and drake with ever after.”
“Trelawney,” said the doctor, “I’ll go with you; and I’ll go bail for it, so will Jim, and be a credit to the undertaking. There’s only one man I’m afraid of.”
“And who’s that?” cried the squire. “Name the dog, sir!”
“You,” replied the doctor; “for you cannot hold your tongue. We are not the only men who know of this paper. These fellows who attacked the inn tonight—bold, desperate blades, for sure—and the rest who stayed aboard that lugger, and more, I dare say, not far off, are, one and all, through thick and thin, bound that they’ll get that money. We must none of us go alone till we get to sea. Jim and I shall stick together in the meanwhile; you’ll take Joyce and Hunter when you ride to Bristol, and from first to last, not one of us must breathe a word of what we’ve found.”
“Livesey,” returned the squire, “you are always in the right of it. I’ll be as silent as the grave.”

Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—.
Dear Livesey—As I do not know whether you are at the hall or still in London, I send this in double to both places.
The ship is bought and fitted. She lies at anchor, ready for sea. You never imagined a sweeter schooner—a child might sail her—two hundred tons; name, Hispaniola.
I got her through my old friend, Blandly, who has proved himself throughout the most surprising trump. The admirable fellow literally slaved in my interest, and so, I may say, did everyone in Bristol, as soon as they got wind of the port we sailed for—treasure, I mean.
“Redruth,” said I, interrupting the letter, “Dr. Livesey will not like that. The squire has been talking, after all.”
“Well, who’s a better right?” growled the gamekeeper. “A pretty rum go if squire ain’t to talk for Dr. Livesey, I should think.”
At that I gave up all attempts at commentary and read straight on:
Blandly himself found the Hispaniola, and by the most admirable management got her for the merest trifle. There is a class of men in Bristol monstrously prejudiced against Blandly. They go the length of declaring that this honest creature would do anything for money, that the Hispaniola belonged to him, and that he sold it me absurdly high—the most transparent calumnies. None of them dare, however, to deny the merits of the ship.
So far there was not a hitch. The workpeople, to be sure—riggers and what not—were most annoyingly slow; but time cured that. It was the crew that troubled me.
I wished a round score of men—in case of natives, buccaneers, or the odious French—and I had the worry of the deuce itself to find so much as half a dozen, till the most remarkable stroke of fortune brought me the very man that I required.
I was standing on the dock, when, by the merest accident, I fell in talk with him. I found he was an old sailor, kept a public-house, knew all the seafaring men in Bristol, had lost his health ashore, and wanted a good berth as cook to get to sea again. He had hobbled down there that morning, he said, to get a smell of the salt.
I was monstrously touched—so would you have been—and, out of pure pity, I engaged him on the spot to be ship’s cook. Long John Silver, he is called, and has lost a leg; but that I regarded as a recommendation, since he lost it in his country’s service, under the immortal Hawke. He has no pension, Livesey. Imagine the abominable age we live in!
Well, sir, I thought I had only found a cook, but it was a crew I had discovered. Between Silver and myself we got together in a few days a company of the toughest old salts imaginable—not pretty to look at, but fellows, by their faces, of the most indomitable spirit. I declare we could fight a frigate.
Long John even got rid of two out of the six or seven I had already engaged. He showed me in a moment that they were just the sort of fresh-water swabs we had to fear in an adventure of importance.
I am in the most magnificent health and spirits, eating like a bull, sleeping like a tree, yet I shall not enjoy a moment till I hear my old tarpaulins tramping round the capstan.

**Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—.**  

The wind howled through the narrow streets of Bristol, rattling the sign of the Old Anchor Inn as though the very devil were shaking it. Inside, the air was thick with the smell of salt, tobacco, and stale ale. Sailors of every sort—some fresh from their voyages, others long ashore—crowded the dimly lit room, their voices rising and falling like the tide.  

I sat in a shadowed corner, nursing a tankard of rum, my eyes fixed on the door. It had been three days since I had last seen the old seaman—the one with the scar across his cheek and the wild look in his eye. He had spoken of treasure, of a map that could make a man richer than the King himself. At first, I had thought him mad, but the way his hands trembled when he spoke of it had planted a seed of doubt in my mind.  

The door creaked open, and a gust of wind sent a flurry of rain into the room. A hush fell over the inn as a figure stepped inside—tall, broad-shouldered, with a face weathered by years at sea. It was not the man I had been waiting for, but there was something about him that commanded attention. He strode to the bar and ordered a drink in a voice like gravel.  

"Seen a man called Billy Bones?" he asked the innkeeper, his eyes scanning the room.  

The innkeeper hesitated, then shook his head. "No, sir. Not in a week or more."  

The stranger’s jaw tightened, and he tossed a coin onto the counter. "If he comes in, tell him Jim Hawkins is looking for him."  

My heart leapt at the name. Jim Hawkins—the same lad who had helped uncover the treasure of Flint’s Island years before. If he was here, then the rumors must be true. The map was real.  

No sooner had the stranger left than the door opened again, and this time, it was the man I had been waiting for—Billy Bones himself, though he looked worse for wear. His face was pale, his hands shaking as he stumbled to a table and called for rum.  

I moved closer, pretending to mind my own business, but my ears were sharp.  

"They’re after me," Bones muttered to himself, his voice barely above a whisper. "Black Dog’s been here, and now Jim Hawkins… They’ll have the map, they will, unless I—"  

He broke off as his eyes met mine, and for a moment, I feared he had seen through my pretense. But then his gaze slid away, and he took another long drink.  

The game was afoot. The treasure was within reach. And I meant to have it.  

*(To be continued...)*

Seaward, ho! Hang the treasure! It’s the glory of the sea that has turned my head. So now, Livesey, come post; do not lose an hour, if you respect me.
Let young Hawkins go at once to see his mother, with Redruth for a guard; and then both come full speed to Bristol. John Trelawney
Postscript.—I did not tell you that Blandly, who, by the way, is to send a consort after us if we don’t turn up by the end of August, had found an admirable fellow for sailing master—a stiff man, which I regret, but in all other respects a treasure. Long John Silver unearthed a very competent man for a mate, a man named Arrow. I have a boatswain who pipes, Livesey; so things shall go man-o’-war fashion on board the good ship Hispaniola.
I forgot to tell you that Silver is a man of substance; I know of my own knowledge that he has a banker’s account, which has never been overdrawn. He leaves his wife to manage the inn; and as she is a woman of colour, a pair of old bachelors like you and I may be excused for guessing that it is the wife, quite as much as the health, that sends him back to roving.
P.P.S.—Hawkins may stay one night with his mother.
You can fancy the excitement into which that letter put me. I was half beside myself with glee; and if ever I despised a man, it was old Tom Redruth, who could do nothing but grumble and lament. Any of the under-gamekeepers would gladly have changed places with him; but such was not the squire’s pleasure, and the squire’s pleasure was like law among them all. Nobody but old Redruth would have dared so much as even to grumble.

Until that moment, his thoughts had been consumed by the adventures ahead, but seeing this unfamiliar boy who would take his place beside his mother brought on his first bout of tears.
Jim confesses he treated the new apprentice harshly, frequently correcting and belittling him, partly due to his own emotional state and the boy's inexperience.

The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits. The captain, who had so long been a cause of so much discomfort, was gone where the wicked cease from troubling. The squire had had everything repaired, and the public rooms and the sign repainted, and had added some furniture—above all a beautiful armchair for mother in the bar. He had found her a boy as an apprentice also so that she should not want help while I was gone.
It was on seeing that boy that I understood, for the first time, my situation. I had thought up to that moment of the adventures before me, not at all of the home that I was leaving; and now, at sight of this clumsy stranger, who was to stay here in my place beside my mother, I had my first attack of tears. I am afraid I led that boy a dog’s life, for as he was new to the work, I had a hundred opportunities of setting him right and putting him down, and I was not slow to profit by them.
The night passed, and the next day, after dinner, Redruth and I were afoot again and on the road. I said good-bye to Mother and the cove where I had lived since I was born, and the dear old Admiral Benbow—since he was repainted, no longer quite so dear. One of my last thoughts was of the captain, who had so often strode along the beach with his cocked hat, his sabre-cut cheek, and his old brass telescope.

The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits. The inn was just as I remembered it—the creaking sign swinging in the breeze, the smell of salt and wood smoke lingering in the air. Though the place had seen better days, it still felt like home.  

My mother greeted us warmly, her face lighting up at the sight of me. She had managed the inn well in my absence, though the shadow of my father’s death still hung over her. Still, she was strong, and the familiar bustle of the inn seemed to keep her busy.  

As we sat by the hearth, Dr. Livesey inquired after the villagers and the latest news. My mother spoke of the usual comings and goings—fishermen, travelers, and the occasional merchant. But then her voice lowered, and she glanced toward the door as if fearing eavesdroppers.  

“There’s been talk,” she said, “of strangers asking after the old seaman—your father’s guest.”  

A chill ran down my spine. The mention of the old pirate, Billy Bones, brought back memories of the map and the treasure. Dr. Livesey’s expression grew serious.  

“What sort of strangers?” he asked.  

“Rough men,” she replied. “Sailors, by the look of them. One had a scar across his cheek—another missing fingers.”  

I exchanged a look with the doctor. The crew of the *Hispaniola* had not been the only ones seeking Flint’s treasure. The hunt was far from over.

“Bristol,” said Tom. “Get down.”
Mr. Trelawney had taken up his residence at an inn far down the docks to superintend the work upon the schooner. Thither we had now to walk, and our way, to my great delight, lay along the quays and beside the great multitude of ships of all sizes and rigs and nations. In one, sailors were singing at their work, in another there were men aloft, high over my head, hanging to threads that seemed no thicker than a spider’s. Though I had lived by the shore all my life, I seemed never to have been near the sea till then. The smell of tar and salt was something new. I saw the most wonderful figureheads, that had all been far over the ocean. I saw, besides, many old sailors, with rings in their ears, and whiskers curled in ringlets, and tarry pigtails, and their swaggering, clumsy sea-walk; and if I had seen as many kings or archbishops I could not have been more delighted.
And I was going to sea myself, to sea in a schooner, with a piping boatswain and pig-tailed singing seamen, to sea, bound for an unknown island, and to seek for buried treasure!

As I was waiting, a man came out of a side room, and at a glance I was sure he must be Long John. His left leg was cut off close by the hip, and under the left shoulder he carried a crutch, which he managed with wonderful dexterity, hopping about upon it like a bird. He was very tall and strong, with a face as big as a ham—plain and pale, but intelligent and smiling. Indeed, he seemed in the most cheerful spirits, whistling as he moved about among the tables, with a merry word or a slap on the shoulder for the more favoured of his guests.
Now, to tell you the truth, from the very first mention of Long John in Squire Trelawney’s letter I had taken a fear in my mind that he might prove to be the very one-legged sailor whom I had watched for so long at the old Benbow. But one look at the man before me was enough. I had seen the captain, and Black Dog, and the blind man, Pew, and I thought I knew what a buccaneer was like—a very different creature, according to me, from this clean and pleasant-tempered landlord.
I plucked up courage at once, crossed the threshold, and walked right up to the man where he stood, propped on his crutch, talking to a customer.
“Mr. Silver, sir?” I asked, holding out the note.
“Yes, my lad,” said he; “such is my name, to be sure. And who may you be?” And then as he saw the squire’s letter, he seemed to me to give something almost like a start.
“Oh!” said he, quite loud, and offering his hand. “I see. You are our new cabin-boy; pleased I am to see you.”
And he took my hand in his large firm grasp.

The man whom he called Morgan—an old, grey-haired, mahogany-faced sailor—came forward pretty sheepishly, rolling his quid.
“Now, Morgan,” said Long John very sternly, “you never clapped your eyes on that Black—Black Dog before, did you, now?”
“Not I, sir,” said Morgan with a salute.
“You didn’t know his name, did you?”
“No, sir.”
“By the powers, Tom Morgan, it’s as good for you!” exclaimed the landlord. “If you had been mixed up with the like of that, you would never have put another foot in my house, you may lay to that. And what was he saying to you?”
“I don’t rightly know, sir,” answered Morgan.
“Do you call that a head on your shoulders, or a blessed dead-eye?” cried Long John. “Don’t rightly know, don’t you! Perhaps you don’t happen to rightly know who you was speaking to, perhaps? Come, now, what was he jawing—v’yages, cap’ns, ships? Pipe up! What was it?”
“We was a-talkin’ of keel-hauling,” answered Morgan.
“Keel-hauling, was you? And a mighty suitable thing, too, and you may lay to that. Get back to your place for a lubber, Tom.”
And then, as Morgan rolled back to his seat, Silver added to me in a confidential whisper that was very flattering, as I thought, “He’s quite an honest man, Tom Morgan, on’y stupid. And now,” he ran on again, aloud, “let’s see—Black Dog? No, I don’t know the name, not I. Yet I kind of think I’ve—yes, I’ve seen the swab. He used to come here with a blind beggar, he used.”
“That he did, you may be sure,” said I. “I knew that blind man too. His name was Pew.”
“It was!” cried Silver, now quite excited. “Pew! That were his name for certain. Ah, he looked a shark, he did! If we run down this Black Dog, now, there’ll be news for Cap’n Trelawney! Ben’s a good runner; few seamen run better than Ben. He should run him down, hand over hand, by the powers! He talked o’ keel-hauling, did he? I’ll keel-haul him!”
All the time he was jerking out these phrases he was stumping up and down the tavern on his crutch, slapping tables with his hand, and giving such a show of excitement as would have convinced an Old Bailey judge or a Bow Street runner. My suspicions had been thoroughly reawakened on finding Black Dog at the Spy-glass, and I watched the cook narrowly. But he was too deep, and too ready, and too clever for me, and by the time the two men had come back out of breath and confessed that they had lost the track in a crowd, and been scolded like thieves, I would have gone bail for the innocence of Long John Silver.

“See here, now, Hawkins,” said he, “here’s a blessed hard thing on a man like me, now, ain’t it? There’s Cap’n Trelawney—what’s he to think? Here I have this confounded son of a Dutchman sitting in my own house drinking of my own rum! Here you comes and tells me of it plain; and here I let him give us all the slip before my blessed deadlights! Now, Hawkins, you do me justice with the cap’n. You’re a lad, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when you first come in. Now, here it is: What could I do, with this old timber I hobble on? When I was an A B master mariner I’d have come up alongside of him, hand over hand, and broached him to in a brace of old shakes, I would; but now—”
And then, all of a sudden, he stopped, and his jaw dropped as though he had remembered something.
“The score!” he burst out. “Three goes o’ rum! Why, shiver my timbers, if I hadn’t forgotten my score!”
And falling on a bench, he laughed until the tears ran down his cheeks. I could not help joining, and we laughed together, peal after peal, until the tavern rang again.
“Why, what a precious old sea-calf I am!” he said at last, wiping his cheeks. “You and me should get on well, Hawkins, for I’ll take my davy I should be rated ship’s boy. But come now, stand by to go about. This won’t do. Dooty is dooty, messmates. I’ll put on my old cockerel hat, and step along of you to Cap’n Trelawney, and report this here affair. For mind you, it’s serious, young Hawkins; and neither you nor me’s come out of it with what I should make so bold as to call credit. Nor you neither, says you; not smart—none of the pair of us smart. But dash my buttons! That was a good un about my score.”
And he began to laugh again, and that so heartily, that though I did not see the joke as he did, I was again obliged to join him in his mirth.

The Hispaniola lay some way out, and we went under the figureheads and round the sterns of many other ships, and their cables sometimes grated underneath our keel, and sometimes swung above us. At last, however, we got alongside, and were met and saluted as we stepped aboard by the mate, Mr. Arrow, a brown old sailor with earrings in his ears and a squint. He and the squire were very thick and friendly, but I soon observed that things were not the same between Mr. Trelawney and the captain.
This last was a sharp-looking man who seemed angry with everything on board and was soon to tell us why, for we had hardly got down into the cabin when a sailor followed us.
“Captain Smollett, sir, axing to speak with you,” said he.
“I am always at the captain’s orders. Show him in,” said the squire.
The captain, who was close behind his messenger, entered at once and shut the door behind him.

events.title: Captain Smollett's Unveiled Discontent
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney initiates the conversation, asking Captain Smollett for his assessment of the ship and preparations.
Captain Smollett responds directly and bluntly, stating his dissatisfaction with the cruise, the crew, and his officer, Mr. Arrow.
Squire Trelawney, visibly angered, challenges Smollett, questioning if he also dislikes the ship and, implicitly, his employer.
Dr. Livesey calmly intervenes, advising against questions likely to cause ill feeling and insists that Smollett must elaborate on his stark pronouncements.
Smollett explains that he was hired under "sealed orders" but has discovered that every crew member below officer rank is better informed about the voyage's details than he is, which he deems unfair.
He reveals that he has learned from his own men that the voyage is a treasure hunt.

Smollett expresses his deep apprehension about treasure voyages in general, particularly those that are meant to be secret but have clearly been compromised, alluding to the widespread knowledge by suggesting the secret was "told to the parrot."
He concludes by stating his belief that neither Trelawney nor Livesey fully comprehend the severe risks involved, which he characterizes as a matter of life or death.

events.text_segment:
“Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?”
“Well, sir,” said the captain, “better speak plain, I believe, even at the risk of offence. I don’t like this cruise; I don’t like the men; and I don’t like my officer. That’s short and sweet.”
“Perhaps, sir, you don’t like the ship?” inquired the squire, very angry, as I could see.
“I can’t speak as to that, sir, not having seen her tried,” said the captain. “She seems a clever craft; more I can’t say.”
“Possibly, sir, you may not like your employer, either?” says the squire.
But here Dr. Livesey cut in.
“Stay a bit,” said he, “stay a bit. No use of such questions as that but to produce ill feeling. The captain has said too much or he has said too little, and I’m bound to say that I require an explanation of his words. You don’t, you say, like this cruise. Now, why?”
“I was engaged, sir, on what we call sealed orders, to sail this ship for that gentleman where he should bid me,” said the captain. “So far so good. But now I find that every man before the mast knows more than I do. I don’t call that fair, now, do you?”
“No,” said Dr. Livesey, “I don’t.”
“Next,” said the captain, “I learn we are going after treasure—hear it from my own hands, mind you. Now, treasure is ticklish work; I don’t like treasure voyages on any account, and I don’t like them, above all, when they are secret and when (begging your pardon, Mr. Trelawney) the secret has been told to the parrot.”
“Silver’s parrot?” asked the squire.
“It’s a way of speaking,” said the captain. “Blabbed, I mean. It’s my belief neither of you gentlemen know what you are about, but I’ll tell you my way of it—life or death, and a close run.”

The words rang out across the deck of the *Hispaniola* as Squire Trelawney, ever the cheerful optimist, clapped Captain Smollett on the shoulder. The captain, however, remained grim-faced, his keen eyes scanning the rigging and the crew with suspicion.

At the mention of Silver, the captain’s jaw tightened. “Aye, and that’s another matter. That one-legged cook is too clever by half. Mark my words, Squire—there’s mischief brewing aboard this ship.”  

Jim Hawkins, listening nearby, felt a chill despite the warm Caribbean sun. He had trusted Silver too, had even admired him. But now, doubts crept in like the tide.

Captain Smollett gave a curt nod. “We’ll see, Silver. We’ll see.”

events.title: Further Complaints and Strategic Precautions
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey acknowledges the captain's points as clear and likely true, accepting the inherent risks of their venture but asserting they are not as naive as Smollett presumes.
Smollett continues his list of grievances, stating he dislikes the crew and believes he should have been responsible for selecting them.
Dr. Livesey concedes that Trelawney perhaps should have involved the captain in hiring, attributing any slight as unintentional.

When questioned about Mr. Arrow, Smollett clarifies that while he considers Arrow a good seaman, he believes Arrow is too informal and familiar with the crew to be an effective officer, emphasizing a mate should maintain distance and not fraternize with ordinary sailors; he specifies this isn't about Arrow drinking, but about undue familiarity.
Pressed by Dr. Livesey for his demands, and after confirming the gentlemen are resolute in proceeding with the cruise (“Like iron,” affirms the Squire), Smollett outlines specific changes.
He proposes relocating the ship's powder and firearms from the fore hold to a more secure position beneath the cabin as his first point.
His second suggestion is to assign berths near the cabin to the four personal retainers Trelawney is bringing, rather than having them berthed forward.

Smollett then raises his third point: the excessive "blabbing" about the mission, revealing he has heard that they possess a treasure map marked with crosses and knows the island's exact latitude and longitude, information the crew also possesses.
Squire Trelawney vehemently denies ever sharing the island's specific location with anyone.

The narrator observes that neither Dr. Livesey nor Captain Smollett seems to give much weight to Trelawney's denial, and indeed, the narrator himself, while acknowledging Trelawney's tendency to be a loose talker, believes Trelawney was truthful in this specific instance about not revealing the island's coordinates.

events.text_segment:
“That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey. “We take the risk, but we are not so ignorant as you believe us. Next, you say you don’t like the crew. Are they not good seamen?”
“I don’t like them, sir,” returned Captain Smollett. “And I think I should have had the choosing of my own hands, if you go to that.”
“Perhaps you should,” replied the doctor. “My friend should, perhaps, have taken you along with him; but the slight, if there be one, was unintentional. And you don’t like Mr. Arrow?”
“I don’t, sir. I believe he’s a good seaman, but he’s too free with the crew to be a good officer. A mate should keep himself to himself—shouldn’t drink with the men before the mast!”
“Do you mean he drinks?” cried the squire.
“No, sir,” replied the captain, “only that he’s too familiar.”
“Well, now, and the short and long of it, captain?” asked the doctor. “Tell us what you want.”
“Well, gentlemen, are you determined to go on this cruise?”
“Like iron,” answered the squire.
“Very good,” said the captain. “Then, as you’ve heard me very patiently, saying things that I could not prove, hear me a few words more. They are putting the powder and the arms in the fore hold. Now, you have a good place under the cabin; why not put them there?—first point. Then, you are bringing four of your own people with you, and they tell me some of them are to be berthed forward. Why not give them the berths here beside the cabin?—second point.”
“Any more?” asked Mr. Trelawney.
“One more,” said the captain. “There’s been too much blabbing already.”
“Far too much,” agreed the doctor.
“I’ll tell you what I’ve heard myself,” continued Captain Smollett: “that you have a map of an island, that there’s crosses on the map to show where treasure is, and that the island lies—” And then he named the latitude and longitude exactly.
“I never told that,” cried the squire, “to a soul!”
“The hands know it, sir,” returned the captain.
“Livesey, that must have been you or Hawkins,” cried the squire.
“It doesn’t much matter who it was,” replied the doctor. And I could see that neither he nor the captain paid much regard to Mr. Trelawney’s protestations. Neither did I, to be sure, he was so loose a talker; yet in this case I believe he was really right and that nobody had told the situation of the island.

“That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey, stroking his chin thoughtfully. “But it leaves us with more questions than answers, does it not?”  

The fire crackled in the hearth of the Admiral Benbow Inn, casting flickering shadows across the faces of those gathered—Dr. Livesey, Squire Trelawney, and young Jim Hawkins. The old sea chest, now empty save for a few scraps of parchment, lay open before them. The map to Flint’s treasure had been found, but the dangers ahead loomed larger than ever.  

“The island’s marked plain enough,” said the squire, tapping the yellowed map with a plump finger. “But what of the men we’ll need to crew the ship? A treasure like this won’t be dug up without strong backs and steady hands.”  

Dr. Livesey frowned. “We must be cautious. Flint’s men are scattered, and some may yet live. If word of this map reaches the wrong ears…” He trailed off, his meaning clear.  

Jim shifted uneasily in his seat. He had seen the violence of pirates firsthand—the blind beggar Pew and his murderous gang had nearly killed his mother and burned down the inn. The thought of facing more such men sent a chill down his spine.  

“Then we keep it quiet,” declared the squire, ever the optimist. “I’ll hire the crew myself, good Devon men who can be trusted. We’ll sail swift and strike hard. Why, within the month, we could be standing atop a fortune!”  

Dr. Livesey sighed. “I hope you’re right, squire. But remember, Flint was a cunning devil. He wouldn’t have buried his treasure without safeguards. There may be more than just a cross on a map to contend with.”  

Jim’s eyes widened. “You mean traps?”  

“Or worse,” the doctor murmured.  

A silence fell over the room, broken only by the wind howling outside. The promise of gold was intoxicating, but the shadows of the past seemed to whisper warnings.  

At last, the squire clapped his hands together. “Enough gloom! We’ve the map, we’ve the will, and by thunder, we’ll have the treasure! Tomorrow, I set to work. The *Hispaniola* will be ready within the fortnight!”  

Dr. Livesey exchanged a glance with Jim, his expression unreadable. The adventure was beginning—but whether it would end in riches or ruin, none could yet say.

“I see,” said the doctor. “You wish us to keep this matter dark and to make a garrison of the stern part of the ship, manned with my friend’s own people, and provided with all the arms and powder on board. In other words, you fear a mutiny.”
“Sir,” said Captain Smollett, “with no intention to take offence, I deny your right to put words into my mouth. No captain, sir, would be justified in going to sea at all if he had ground enough to say that. As for Mr. Arrow, I believe him thoroughly honest; some of the men are the same; all may be for what I know. But I am responsible for the ship’s safety and the life of every man Jack aboard of her. I see things going, as I think, not quite right. And I ask you to take certain precautions or let me resign my berth. And that’s all.”
“Captain Smollett,” began the doctor with a smile, “did ever you hear the fable of the mountain and the mouse? You’ll excuse me, I dare say, but you remind me of that fable. When you came in here, I’ll stake my wig, you meant more than this.”
“Doctor,” said the captain, “you are smart. When I came in here I meant to get discharged. I had no thought that Mr. Trelawney would hear a word.”
“No more I would,” cried the squire. “Had Livesey not been here I should have seen you to the deuce. As it is, I have heard you. I will do as you desire, but I think the worse of you.”
“That’s as you please, sir,” said the captain. “You’ll find I do my duty.”
And with that he took his leave.

“Well, gentlemen,” continued the captain, “I don’t know who has this map; but I make it a point, it shall be kept secret even from me and Mr. Arrow. Otherwise I would ask you to let me resign.”  

A tense silence fell over the room. The flickering candlelight cast long shadows across the faces of the assembled men—squires, doctors, and sailors alike. The weight of the captain’s words hung heavy in the air.  

Dr. Livesey cleared his throat. “Captain Smollett, your concern is understandable. But surely, if we are to trust one another in this venture—”  

“Trust is one thing, Doctor,” the captain interrupted, his voice firm. “Discipline is another. If every man aboard knows the course we steer, or worse, the treasure’s location, then mutiny is but a whisper away. I’ve seen it before.”  

Squire Trelawney shifted uncomfortably in his seat. “But surely, Captain, you don’t suspect *us* of—”  

“I suspect no one, Squire,” Smollett replied. “But I know the sea, and I know men. Gold does strange things to even the best of them.”  

Mr. Arrow, the first mate, nodded in agreement, though his expression was uneasy. The captain’s insistence on secrecy clearly unsettled him.  

At last, Dr. Livesey sighed. “Very well, Captain. The map shall remain hidden, known only to those absolutely necessary. But mark my words—secrets have a way of unraveling at the worst possible moment.”  

The captain’s stern face softened slightly. “Aye, Doctor. But better that than a knife in the dark.”  

With that, the meeting adjourned, each man lost in his own thoughts. The hunt for Flint’s treasure had begun, but already, the seeds of doubt had been sown.

events.title: Aftermath, Reflections, and Ship Reorganization
detailed_summary: Following Captain Smollett's departure, Dr. Livesey remarks to Squire Trelawney that, contrary to his expectations, Trelawney has managed to secure two honest individuals for the voyage: Captain Smollett and John Silver.

Squire Trelawney readily agrees regarding John Silver's honesty but expresses strong disdain for Captain Smollett, describing his conduct as unmanly, unsailorly, and un-English; Dr. Livesey cautiously responds, "Well, we shall see."

Upon returning to the deck, the narrator observes that the crew has already commenced the work of relocating the arms and powder, singing as they labor, while Captain Smollett and Mr. Arrow oversee the operations.

The narrator describes the newly implemented arrangements, which he personally finds agreeable; the schooner's layout has been significantly altered, with six berths created aft from part of the main hold.
These cabins are now connected to the galley and forecastle only by a narrow, sparred passage on the port side.

The original plan for these aft berths (intended for the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire) is changed; Redruth and the narrator (Jim Hawkins) are now assigned two of these secure berths.

Consequently, Mr. Arrow and Captain Smollett are to sleep on deck in the companionway, which has been enlarged on each side to accommodate two hammocks, almost resembling a round-house, though still low.

The narrator notes that even Mr. Arrow seemed pleased with this new arrangement, speculating that perhaps Arrow also had reservations about the crew, though this is only a guess as Arrow's opinion would not be available for long.

“Trelawney,” said the doctor, “contrary to all my notions, I believed you have managed to get two honest men on board with you—that man and John Silver.”
“Silver, if you like,” cried the squire; “but as for that intolerable humbug, I declare I think his conduct unmanly, unsailorly, and downright un-English.”
“Well,” says the doctor, “we shall see.”
When we came on deck, the men had begun already to take out the arms and powder, yo-ho-ing at their work, while the captain and Mr. Arrow stood by superintending.
The new arrangement was quite to my liking. The whole schooner had been overhauled; six berths had been made astern out of what had been the after-part of the main hold; and this set of cabins was only joined to the galley and forecastle by a sparred passage on the port side. It had been originally meant that the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire were to occupy these six berths. Now Redruth and I were to get two of them and Mr. Arrow and the captain were to sleep on deck in the companion, which had been enlarged on each side till you might almost have called it a round-house. Very low it was still, of course; but there was room to swing two hammocks, and even the mate seemed pleased with the arrangement. Even he, perhaps, had been doubtful as to the crew, but that is only guess, for as you shall hear, we had not long the benefit of his opinion.

events.title: Long John Silver's Arrival and Captain Smollett's Stern Authority
detailed_summary: While everyone is engaged in relocating the powder and reconfiguring the berths, Long John Silver arrives with the last of the shore party.

Silver, agilely boarding the ship “like a monkey for cleverness,” immediately notices the ongoing work and inquires about it, expressing concern that the changes might cause them to miss the morning tide.
Captain Smollett briefly and authoritatively informs Silver that these are his orders and directs him to go below, as the crew will soon require supper.
Silver respectfully complies, touching his forelock before heading to his galley.
Dr. Livesey commends Silver to the captain, calling him a good man; Captain Smollett offers a noncommittal "Very likely, sir."
The captain continues to direct the men moving the powder, cautioning them to be careful.
Spotting the narrator, Jim Hawkins, examining the ship's swivel gun (a long brass nine-pounder), Captain Smollett sharply orders him away, telling him to find work with the cook.
As the narrator hurries off, he overhears Captain Smollett loudly declare to Dr. Livesey his intention to have no favorites on his ship.
The narrator concludes by stating that he fully shared Squire Trelawney's negative assessment of Captain Smollett at that moment, feeling a deep animosity towards him.

We were all hard at work, changing the powder and the berths, when the last man or two, and Long John along with them, came off in a shore-boat.
The cook came up the side like a monkey for cleverness, and as soon as he saw what was doing, “So ho, mates!” says he. “What’s this?”
“We’re a-changing of the powder, Jack,” answers one.
“Why, by the powers,” cried Long John, “if we do, we’ll miss the morning tide!”
“My orders!” said the captain shortly. “You may go below, my man. Hands will want supper.”
“Aye, aye, sir,” answered the cook, and touching his forelock, he disappeared at once in the direction of his galley.
“That’s a good man, captain,” said the doctor.
“Very likely, sir,” replied Captain Smollett. “Easy with that, men—easy,” he ran on, to the fellows who were shifting the powder; and then suddenly observing me examining the swivel we carried amidships, a long brass nine, “Here you, ship’s boy,” he cried, “out o’ that! Off with you to the cook and get some work.”
And then as I was hurrying off I heard him say, quite loudly, to the doctor, “I’ll have no favourites on my ship.”
I assure you I was quite of the squire’s way of thinking, and hated the captain deeply.

events.title: Departure Preparations and the Hispaniola Sets Sail with a Shanty
detailed_summary: The night before departure was chaotic with preparations and well-wishers visiting the squire.
Jim Hawkins found the work more strenuous than any night at the Admiral Benbow, leaving him extremely tired.
Despite his fatigue, Jim remained on deck, captivated by the novel sights and sounds of the ship preparing to sail before dawn.
He observed the quick commands, the boatswain's whistle, and the crew moving in the lamplight to man the capstan-bars.
A crew member requested Long John Silver, addressed as Barbecue, to sing a song.
Silver, using his crutch, readily agreed and began the familiar shanty, "Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest."
The entire crew joined in the chorus, "Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!", pushing the capstan bars with enthusiasm.
The song and the moment transported Jim back to the Admiral Benbow, imagining the old captain's voice in the singing.

events.text_segment:
All that night we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in their place, and boatfuls of the squire’s friends, Mr. Blandly and the like, coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return. We never had a night at the Admiral Benbow when I had half the work; and I was dog-tired when, a little before dawn, the boatswain sounded his pipe and the crew began to man the capstan-bars. I might have been twice as weary, yet I would not have left the deck, all was so new and interesting to me—the brief commands, the shrill note of the whistle, the men bustling to their places in the glimmer of the ship’s lanterns.
“Now, Barbecue, tip us a stave,” cried one voice.
“The old one,” cried another.
“Aye, aye, mates,” said Long John, who was standing by, with his crutch under his arm, and at once broke out in the air and words I knew so well:
“Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—”
And then the whole crew bore chorus:—
“Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
And at the third “Ho!” drove the bars before them with a will.
Even at that exciting moment it carried me back to the old Admiral Benbow in a second, and I seemed to hear the voice of the captain piping in the chorus.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared. He had no command among the men, and people did what they pleased with him. But that was by no means the worst of it, for after a day or two at sea he began to appear on deck with hazy eye, red cheeks, stuttering tongue, and other marks of drunkenness. Time after time he was ordered below in disgrace. Sometimes he fell and cut himself; sometimes he lay all day long in his little bunk at one side of the companion; sometimes for a day or two he would be almost sober and attend to his work at least passably.
In the meantime, we could never make out where he got the drink. That was the ship’s mystery. Watch him as we pleased, we could do nothing to solve it; and when we asked him to his face, he would only laugh if he were drunk, and if he were sober deny solemnly that he ever tasted anything but water.
He was not only useless as an officer and a bad influence amongst the men, but it was plain that at this rate he must soon kill himself outright, so nobody was much surprised, nor very sorry, when one dark night, with a head sea, he disappeared entirely and was seen no more.
“Overboard!” said the captain. “Well, gentlemen, that saves the trouble of putting him in irons.”

events.text_segment:
Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible. It was something to see him wedge the foot of the crutch against a bulkhead, and propped against it, yielding to every movement of the ship, get on with his cooking like someone safe ashore. Still more strange was it to see him in the heaviest of weather cross the deck. He had a line or two rigged up to help him across the widest spaces—Long John’s earrings, they were called; and he would hand himself from one place to another, now using the crutch, now trailing it alongside by the lanyard, as quickly as another man could walk. Yet some of the men who had sailed with him before expressed their pity to see him so reduced.
“He’s no common man, Barbecue,” said the coxswain to me. “He had good schooling in his young days and can speak like a book when so minded; and brave—a lion’s nothing alongside of Long John! I seen him grapple four and knock their heads together—him unarmed.”
All the crew respected and even obeyed him. He had a way of talking to each and doing everybody some particular service. To me he was unweariedly kind, and always glad to see me in the galley, which he kept as clean as a new pin, the dishes hanging up burnished and his parrot in a cage in one corner.
“Come away, Hawkins,” he would say; “come and have a yarn with John. Nobody more welcome than yourself, my son. Sit you down and hear the news. Here’s Cap’n Flint—I calls my parrot Cap’n Flint, after the famous buccaneer—here’s Cap’n Flint predicting success to our v’yage. Wasn’t you, Cap’n?”
And the parrot would say, with great rapidity, “Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!” till you wondered that it was not out of breath, or till John threw his handkerchief over the cage.
“Now, that bird,” he would say, “is, maybe, two hundred years old, Hawkins—they live forever mostly; and if anybody’s seen more wickedness, it must be the devil himself. She’s sailed with England, the great Cap’n England, the pirate. She’s been at Madagascar, and at Malabar, and Surinam, and Providence, and Portobello. She was at the fishing up of the wrecked plate ships. It’s there she learned ‘Pieces of eight,’ and little wonder; three hundred and fifty thousand of ’em, Hawkins! She was at the boarding of the Viceroy of the Indies out of Goa, she was; and to look at her you would think she was a babby. But you smelt powder—didn’t you, Cap’n?”
“Stand by to go about,” the parrot would scream.
“Ah, she’s a handsome craft, she is,” the cook would say, and give her sugar from his pocket, and then the bird would peck at the bars and swear straight on, passing belief for wickedness. “There,” John would add, “you can’t touch pitch and not be mucked, lad. Here’s this poor old innocent bird o’ mine swearing blue fire, and none the wiser, you may lay to that. She would swear the same, in a manner of speaking, before chaplain.” And John would touch his forelock with a solemn way he had that made me think he was the best of men.

Aboard the *Hispaniola*, Long John Silver moved with surprising agility despite his missing leg. His wooden crutch, polished smooth by years of use, swung from a lanyard around his neck, leaving both hands free for whatever task demanded his attention. Whether hauling ropes, adjusting sails, or swabbing the deck, Silver worked with the ease of a man who had spent a lifetime at sea. The crew respected him—not just for his skill, but for the way he carried himself, as though his disability were no hindrance at all.  

Jim Hawkins often watched him from a distance, marveling at how the cook could balance so effortlessly on the rolling deck. Silver would laugh, his one good eye twinkling, and say, *"A man’s worth isn’t in his legs, lad, but in his wits and his will!"* And indeed, Silver’s wits were as sharp as the knife he kept tucked in his belt.  

But there was something unsettling in the way that crutch dangled when Silver wasn’t using it. Jim noticed how, in moments of tension, the cook’s fingers would brush against it, as if reassuring himself it was still there. And once, during a fierce squall, when the ship pitched violently, Silver had seized the crutch mid-swing and used it like a club to steady himself against the mast—quick as a cat, despite the storm’s fury.  

The pirates, too, watched Silver closely. They knew that crutch was more than just a tool for walking. In the dim light below decks, where whispers of mutiny slithered like rats in the hold, the crutch became a weapon. A swift, unexpected strike could silence a man before he had time to cry out. And Silver, with his hands always free, was never caught unprepared.  

Even Captain Smollett, though wary of Silver’s charm, had to admit the man was invaluable. "A one-legged sailor who moves better than most with two," he muttered once to Dr. Livesey. "But mark my words—there’s more to that crutch than meets the eye."  

And he was right. For when the time came, when the mutiny erupted like gunpowder set alight, Silver’s crutch was no longer just a support—it was a symbol of his cunning. He could hobble forward, smiling, hands raised in peace, while the lanyard kept his weapon close. And when the moment demanded it, that same crutch could become a cudgel, a barrier, or even a lifeline.  

In the end, Jim realized the truth: Long John Silver’s greatest strength wasn’t in his arms or his remaining leg—it was in the way he turned every weakness into an advantage. Even a missing limb became a tool, and a simple crutch, hanging innocently from his neck, was the deadliest thing aboard the *Hispaniola*.

In the meantime, the squire and Captain Smollett were still on pretty distant terms with one another. The squire made no bones about the matter; he despised the captain. The captain, on his part, never spoke but when he was spoken to, and then sharp and short and dry, and not a word wasted. He owned, when driven into a corner, that he seemed to have been wrong about the crew, that some of them were as brisk as he wanted to see and all had behaved fairly well. As for the ship, he had taken a downright fancy to her. “She’ll lie a point nearer the wind than a man has a right to expect of his own married wife, sir. But,” he would add, “all I say is, we’re not home again, and I don’t like the cruise.”
The squire, at this, would turn away and march up and down the deck, chin in air.
“A trifle more of that man,” he would say, “and I shall explode.”
We had some heavy weather, which only proved the qualities of the Hispaniola. detailed_summary: Silver clarifies his role under Captain Flint was quartermaster, not captain, and mentions losing his leg in the same naval action where old Pew lost his eyesight.

He laments the fate of the skilled surgeon who amputated his leg, hanged at Corso Castle, and expresses his belief that ships should retain their original names, citing the Cassandra and Flint's old ship, the Walrus, which he recalls being stained with blood and heavy with gold.
The youngest sailor present voices admiration for Flint, calling him the 'flower of the flock'.
Silver acknowledges Davis as a capable pirate but states his own service was first with England, then with Flint, and now he operates independently.
He reveals his financial prudence, having saved nine hundred pounds from his time with England and two thousand after Flint, emphasizing that saving, not merely earning, is crucial.

He contrasts his own financial security with the current state of England's and Flint's former crewmen, many of whom are now impoverished and serving on their current ship, having previously been reduced to begging.
Silver uses Old Pew as an example of profligacy, describing how Pew squandered twelve hundred pounds annually before ending up starving, begging, stealing, and murdering, ultimately dying destitute.
The young seaman remarks that such a life seems ultimately futile.
Silver counters that it's only futile for fools and then begins to flatter the young seaman, calling him intelligent, using the exact same compliments he had previously used on Jim Hawkins.
Jim, concealed in the apple barrel, is filled with rage upon hearing Silver's manipulative flattery directed at another, wishing he could kill him.

No, not I,” said Silver. “Flint was cap’n; I was quartermaster, along of my timber leg. The same broadside I lost my leg, old Pew lost his deadlights. It was a master surgeon, him that ampytated me—out of college and all—Latin by the bucket, and what not; but he was hanged like a dog, and sun-dried like the rest, at Corso Castle. That was Roberts’ men, that was, and comed of changing names to their ships—Royal Fortune and so on. Now, what a ship was christened, so let her stay, I says. So it was with the Cassandra, as brought us all safe home from Malabar, after England took the Viceroy of the Indies; so it was with the old Walrus, Flint’s old ship, as I’ve seen amuck with the red blood and fit to sink with gold.”
“Ah!” cried another voice, that of the youngest hand on board, and evidently full of admiration. “He was the flower of the flock, was Flint!”
“Davis was a man too, by all accounts,” said Silver. “I never sailed along of him; first with England, then with Flint, that’s my story; and now here on my own account, in a manner of speaking. I laid by nine hundred safe, from England, and two thousand after Flint. That ain’t bad for a man before the mast—all safe in bank. ’Tain’t earning now, it’s saving does it, you may lay to that. Where’s all England’s men now? I dunno. Where’s Flint’s? Why, most on ’em aboard here, and glad to get the duff—been begging before that, some on ’em. Old Pew, as had lost his sight, and might have thought shame, spends twelve hundred pound in a year, like a lord in Parliament. Where is he now? Well, he’s dead now and under hatches; but for two year before that, shiver my timbers, the man was starving! He begged, and he stole, and he cut throats, and starved at that, by the powers!”
“Well, it ain’t much use, after all,” said the young seaman.
“’Tain’t much use for fools, you may lay to it—that, nor nothing,” cried Silver. “But now, you look here: you’re young, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when I set my eyes on you, and I’ll talk to you like a man.”
You may imagine how I felt when I heard this abominable old rogue addressing another in the very same words of flattery as he had used to myself. I think, if I had been able, that I would have killed him through the barrel. Meantime, he ran on, little supposing he was overheard.

"No, not I," said Silver, his voice smooth as oil, though his eyes gleamed with a dangerous light. "I ain't the sort to turn on me mates, not like some I could name." He leaned back in his chair, the wooden leg creaking under his weight, and took a slow sip of rum. The firelight flickered across his weathered face, casting deep shadows that seemed to shift with his every word.  

The others in the room shifted uneasily. They knew Long John Silver well enough to recognize when he was playing a game—though none could say for certain what the rules were.  

Jim Hawkins, standing near the door, felt his pulse quicken. He had seen Silver’s cunning firsthand, had watched him charm and deceive with equal ease. The man was a master of twisting words, of making treachery sound like loyalty.  

"You speak fine words, John," growled one of the pirates, a burly man with a scar running down his cheek. "But words won’t fill our pockets with gold."  

Silver’s smile never wavered. "Aye, Tom, and that’s the truth of it. But haste makes waste, as they say. We’ve got the map, haven’t we? And where’s the sense in squabblin’ when Flint’s treasure’s still out there, waitin’ for the takin’?"  

A murmur ran through the room. The mention of Flint’s treasure was enough to stir even the most doubtful among them. Silver knew it, of course. He had played this hand before.  

Jim clenched his fists, fighting the urge to speak. He had seen the map, had heard the stories of the island’s dangers. Silver’s promises were honeyed poison, and these men were too greedy to taste the bitterness beneath.  

Then Silver’s gaze slid toward him, sharp as a knife. "Young Jim here," he said, "he’s been a right proper help, ain’t he? Brave lad, smart too. Why, without him, we might never have found old Flint’s clues."  

The pirates turned their eyes on Jim, some nodding, others scowling. He felt the weight of their stares like a noose tightening.  

Silver took another sip, his smile widening. "Aye, we’re all partners in this venture. And partners share alike—when the time is right."  

But Jim knew better. Silver’s idea of sharing was keeping the lion’s share for himself. And if anyone stood in his way… well, Jim had seen what happened to those who crossed Long John Silver.  

The fire crackled, the only sound in the tense silence. Somewhere outside, the wind howled like a warning.

They was the roughest crew afloat, was Flint’s; the devil himself would have been feared to go to sea with them. Well now, I tell you, I’m not a boasting man, and you seen yourself how easy I keep company, but when I was quartermaster, lambs wasn’t the word for Flint’s old buccaneers. Ah, you may be sure of yourself in old John’s ship.”

Here it is about gentlemen of fortune. They lives rough, and they risk swinging, but they eat and drink like fighting-cocks, and when a cruise is done, why, it’s hundreds of pounds instead of hundreds of farthings in their pockets. Before the mast, like you!”

This was the philosophy of Long John Silver, as he sat in the parlour of the *Admiral Benbow* inn, his wooden leg propped up before him, his crutch leaning against the wall. His words were smooth as molasses, but his eyes—sharp as a cutlass—never left the face of young Jim Hawkins, who listened with a mixture of fascination and dread. 

Silver was a man who knew the value of patience, of biding his time. He had served under captains both cruel and kind, had seen mutinies flare up and die down like squalls at sea, and had learned that the true art of piracy lay not in reckless bloodshed, but in cunning. A man could be rich as Croesus one day and swinging from the gallows the next—unless he had the wit to plan ahead. 

“Now, Jim,” he continued, leaning forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper, “you’re a lad of spirit, and sharp as a marlinspike. There’s them that’s meant to follow orders, and them that’s meant to give ’em. Which do you reckon you are?” 

Jim swallowed hard. The firelight flickered over Silver’s weathered face, casting shadows that seemed to shift like the tide. There was danger here, but also opportunity—the kind that didn’t come twice. 

For in the world of gentlemen of fortune, a man’s fate was his own to make… or to break.

events.title: Dick Commits to Mutiny; Israel Hands Expresses Impatience
detailed_summary: Dick confesses to Silver that he was initially apprehensive about their mutinous undertaking but, after their conversation, is now fully committed, sealing his pledge with a handshake.
Silver commends Dick for his bravery and intelligence, shaking his hand so vigorously that the apple barrel where Jim is hiding trembles.
Jim, overhearing this exchange, fully grasps that 'gentleman of fortune' is a euphemism for pirate and realizes he has witnessed the final stage of an honest sailor's corruption.
Silver then whistles, summoning a third man, who is revealed to be Israel Hands, the ship's coxswain.
Silver informs Hands that Dick has joined their conspiracy ('Dick's square').
Hands acknowledges Dick's allegiance, remarking that Dick is not a fool.

Hands then voices his impatience, complaining about Captain Smollett's command and questioning how long they must wait before seizing control of the ship and its desirable stores, such as pickles and wine.
Silver admonishes Israel for his poor judgment, instructing him to remain in his designated area, maintain a low profile, and stay sober until he gives the order to act.
Israel grumbles in reluctant agreement but persists in asking when they will proceed with their plan.

events.text_segment:
“Well, I tell you now,” replied the lad, “I didn’t half a quarter like the job till I had this talk with you, John; but there’s my hand on it now.”
“And a brave lad you were, and smart too,” answered Silver, shaking hands so heartily that all the barrel shook, “and a finer figurehead for a gentleman of fortune I never clapped my eyes on.”
By this time I had begun to understand the meaning of their terms. By a “gentleman of fortune” they plainly meant neither more nor less than a common pirate, and the little scene that I had overheard was the last act in the corruption of one of the honest hands—perhaps of the last one left aboard. But on this point I was soon to be relieved, for Silver giving a little whistle, a third man strolled up and sat down by the party.
“Dick’s square,” said Silver.
“Oh, I know’d Dick was square,” returned the voice of the coxswain, Israel Hands. “He’s no fool, is Dick.” And he turned his quid and spat. “But look here,” he went on, “here’s what I want to know, Barbecue: how long are we a-going to stand off and on like a blessed bumboat? I’ve had a’most enough o’ Cap’n Smollett; he’s hazed me long enough, by thunder! I want to go into that cabin, I do. I want their pickles and wines, and that.”
“Israel,” said Silver, “your head ain’t much account, nor ever was. But you’re able to hear, I reckon; leastways, your ears is big enough. Now, here’s what I say: you’ll berth forward, and you’ll live hard, and you’ll speak soft, and you’ll keep sober till I give the word; and you may lay to that, my son.”
“Well, I don’t say no, do I?” growled the coxswain. “What I say is, when? That’s what I say.”

“Well, I tell you now,” replied the lad, “I didn’t half a quarter like the job till I had this talk with you, John; but there’s my hand on it now.”  

John Silver’s eyes gleamed with satisfaction as he clasped the boy’s hand in his own gnarled grip. “That’s the spirit, lad! Ye’ve got the makings of a true adventurer in ye. Why, with a bit o’ luck, we’ll be swimming in gold before the year’s out!”  

The boy, though still uneasy, felt a strange thrill at the pirate’s words. The promise of treasure, of danger and glory, stirred something deep within him. Yet, as he looked into Silver’s cunning face, a shadow of doubt crossed his mind. Was this man to be trusted?  

Silver, ever perceptive, seemed to read his thoughts. “Now, now, none o’ that hesitation, my boy. A man’s word is his bond, and I’ve given ye mine. We’re partners in this, fair and square.”  

The boy nodded, though his heart still fluttered like a trapped bird. The deal was struck, and there was no turning back. The island loomed ahead, its dark forests and jagged peaks hiding secrets untold. Somewhere in its depths lay Flint’s treasure—riches beyond imagining.  

But as the ship drew nearer, the boy couldn’t shake the feeling that the real danger wasn’t the island itself, nor the treacherous reefs that guarded it, but the men who sought its gold. And chief among them was Long John Silver, with his smooth words and sharper wits.  

The die was cast. The boy had given his word. Now, he could only hope he hadn’t made a bargain with the devil himself.

events.title: Silver Details His Mutiny Strategy and Criticizes Crew's Recklessness
detailed_summary: Silver emphatically states his intention to delay the mutiny until the very last feasible moment.
He outlines his strategy: to allow Captain Smollett to navigate the ship, and for the squire and doctor to locate the treasure and assist in loading it aboard before the mutineers make their move.
He expresses a desire, were his crew more trustworthy, to have Smollett sail them halfway back to their destination before seizing control.
Dick interjects, suggesting that all of them aboard are capable seamen.
Silver dismisses this, clarifying that they are merely 'forecastle hands' skilled at steering but lacking the expertise to set a course, a common failing he attributes to pirates generally.

He reveals his preference to have Captain Smollett navigate them back into the trade winds to ensure a safe voyage and adequate provisions, but concedes he will likely have to deal with the officers at the island once the treasure is secured, expressing frustration with his crew's fixation on immediate drunkenness.
Israel Hands advises Silver to remain calm and asks who is opposing his plans.
Silver retorts by recounting his extensive maritime experience, having witnessed numerous ships captured and many young sailors executed due to their haste and impatience.
He argues that with discipline and careful planning, they could achieve great wealth, but their impulsiveness and craving for immediate gratification, particularly rum, will be their undoing.
Israel counters, likening Silver to a moralizing chaplain and suggesting that other pirates who enjoyed life's pleasures were also competent, not as austere as Silver.
Silver dismissively cites the fates of Pew, who died a beggar, and Flint, who died from alcoholism in Savannah, as examples of such pleasure-seeking pirates, questioning their ultimate success.

events.text_segment:
“When! By the powers!” cried Silver. “Well now, if you want to know, I’ll tell you when. The last moment I can manage, and that’s when. Here’s a first-rate seaman, Cap’n Smollett, sails the blessed ship for us. Here’s this squire and doctor with a map and such—I don’t know where it is, do I? No more do you, says you. Well then, I mean this squire and doctor shall find the stuff, and help us to get it aboard, by the powers. Then we’ll see. If I was sure of you all, sons of double Dutchmen, I’d have Cap’n Smollett navigate us half-way back again before I struck.”
“Why, we’re all seamen aboard here, I should think,” said the lad Dick.
“We’re all forecastle hands, you mean,” snapped Silver. “We can steer a course, but who’s to set one? That’s what all you gentlemen split on, first and last. If I had my way, I’d have Cap’n Smollett work us back into the trades at least; then we’d have no blessed miscalculations and a spoonful of water a day. But I know the sort you are. I’ll finish with ’em at the island, as soon’s the blunt’s on board, and a pity it is. But you’re never happy till you’re drunk. Split my sides, I’ve a sick heart to sail with the likes of you!”
“Easy all, Long John,” cried Israel. “Who’s a-crossin’ of you?”
“Why, how many tall ships, think ye, now, have I seen laid aboard? And how many brisk lads drying in the sun at Execution Dock?” cried Silver. “And all for this same hurry and hurry and hurry. You hear me? I seen a thing or two at sea, I have. If you would on’y lay your course, and a p’int to windward, you would ride in carriages, you would. But not you! I know you. You’ll have your mouthful of rum tomorrow, and go hang.”
“Everybody knowed you was a kind of a chapling, John; but there’s others as could hand and steer as well as you,” said Israel. “They liked a bit o’ fun, they did. They wasn’t so high and dry, nohow, but took their fling, like jolly companions every one.”
“So?” says Silver. “Well, and where are they now? Pew was that sort, and he died a beggar-man. Flint was, and he died of rum at Savannah. Ah, they was a sweet crew, they was! On’y, where are they?”

“When! By the powers!” cried Silver, his face twisting into a snarl. “If that don’t beat all! Here we are, within sight of the treasure, and now this cursed mutiny rears its ugly head again!”  

The crew had grown restless, their whispers turning to open defiance. The promise of gold had kept them in line, but now that Flint’s treasure was nearly within reach, their greed had turned to suspicion. Hands clenched around cutlasses, eyes darted between Silver and the distant gleam of the island’s hills.  

“Listen to me, you fools!” Silver roared, his voice cutting through the murmurs. “We’ve come this far by sticking together, and by thunder, we’ll finish it the same way! Any man who thinks to cross me now will answer to this!” He slapped the hilt of his pistol, his one good leg planted firmly on the deck.  

A hush fell over the men, but the tension remained thick as fog. I watched from the shadows, my heart pounding. Jim Hawkins knew better than to trust Long John Silver, but even I had to admit—his command over the crew was slipping.  

Then, from the crow’s nest, a shout rang out. “Land ho! The marker’s in sight!”  

All eyes turned toward the island. There, atop the tallest hill, stood the skeletal remains of a great tree—Flint’s landmark. The treasure was near.  

Silver’s grin returned, though it didn’t reach his eyes. “There you have it, lads! Fortune smiles upon us still. Now, who’s with me to claim what’s ours?”  

A ragged cheer went up, but I saw the doubt in their faces. The hunt for Flint’s gold had turned them into wolves, and Silver knew it. If the treasure wasn’t where he promised, blood would spill.  

As the anchor dropped and the boats were readied, I slipped away, my mind racing. The real battle wasn’t over the treasure—it was over who would survive to take it. And I intended to make sure it wasn’t Silver.

events.title: Mutineers Plan Murder; Jim Overhears Crucial News and Land is Sighted
detailed_summary: Dick inquires about the intended fate of the loyal crew members after the mutineers seize control.

Silver commends Dick for his pragmatic question and contrasts two historical approaches: Captain England's method of marooning captives, versus the more brutal tactic of outright slaughter favored by Captain Flint or Billy Bones.
Israel Hands affirms Billy Bones's ruthlessness, recalling his maxim that 'dead men don't bite,' and noting that Bones himself is now deceased.

Silver acknowledges Billy's 'rough and ready' nature but asserts that despite his own generally amiable disposition, the current situation demands severity; he casts his vote for killing all loyalists.

He explains his reasoning: he wants no survivors ('sea-lawyers') to potentially reappear and threaten his comfortable retirement. He advocates patience until the opportune moment, then decisive, lethal action.
Israel Hands expresses admiration for Silver's resolute stance.
Silver then declares his personal intention to kill Trelawney, graphically vowing to wring his neck. He then abruptly asks Dick to fetch him an apple to 'wet his pipe'.
Jim, still hidden in the apple barrel, is overcome with terror at Silver's request, feeling too paralyzed to escape.
As Dick begins to rise, Israel Hands intervenes, suggesting they have rum instead, disparaging the apples as 'bilge'.
Silver agrees, providing Dick with the key to the rum keg but cautioning him about the gauge, implying a need for rationing.
Jim reflects that this secretive provision of alcohol must have been how Mr. Arrow, a former officer, was supplied with the spirits that led to his downfall.

While Dick is briefly absent fetching the rum, Jim overhears a crucial snippet of conversation between Israel and Silver: 'Not another man of them'll jine.' This reveals to Jim that there are still crew members loyal to the captain.

Upon Dick's return, the three mutineers take turns drinking from the pannikin, offering toasts to 'luck,' 'old Flint,' and Silver leading a chant-like toast to themselves, future prizes, and plentiful food.
At that moment, moonlight illuminates Jim's hiding place in the barrel. Simultaneously, the lookout's cry of 'Land ho!' pierces the night.

“But,” asked Dick, “when we do lay ’em athwart, what are we to do with ’em, anyhow?”
“There’s the man for me!” cried the cook admiringly. “That’s what I call business. Well, what would you think? Put ’em ashore like maroons? That would have been England’s way. Or cut ’em down like that much pork? That would have been Flint’s, or Billy Bones’s.”
“Billy was the man for that,” said Israel. “‘Dead men don’t bite,’ says he. Well, he’s dead now hisself; he knows the long and short on it now; and if ever a rough hand come to port, it was Billy.”
“Right you are,” said Silver; “rough and ready. But mark you here, I’m an easy man—I’m quite the gentleman, says you; but this time it’s serious. Dooty is dooty, mates. I give my vote—death. When I’m in Parlyment and riding in my coach, I don’t want none of these sea-lawyers in the cabin a-coming home, unlooked for, like the devil at prayers.
