“You seem to have a lot to say,” remarked Silver, spitting far into the air. “Pipe up and let me hear it, or lay to.”

The words hung heavy in the salty breeze, and for a moment, the only sound was the creaking of the *Hispaniola* as she swayed gently at anchor. The men gathered on deck shifted uneasily, their eyes darting between Long John Silver and the man who had dared to mutter under his breath—Tom Morgan, a burly sailor with a face like weathered oak.

Morgan clenched his fists, his knuckles white. “Aye, I’ve got something to say,” he growled. “We’ve been sitting here nigh on a week, waiting for the tide, waiting for the wind, waiting for Flint’s cursed treasure to dig itself up. And what do we have to show for it? Empty bellies and empty hands!”

A murmur of agreement rippled through the crew. Silver’s single eye gleamed like a shard of broken glass as he studied them, his crutch planted firmly on the deck. He knew mutiny when he smelled it, and the stench was thick in the air.

“Is that so, Tom?” Silver’s voice was deceptively soft, like the purr of a cat before it strikes. “And what would you have us do, eh? Sail off into the blue without a chart, without a bearing? Or maybe you’d like to take a stroll ashore and ask the ghosts of them that’s gone before us where the treasure lies?”

Morgan’s face darkened. “I ain’t saying that. But Flint’s map is in our hands, and every hour we waste is another hour them others might be plotting against us. That doctor and the squire—they ain’t fools. They’ll be coming for what’s theirs.”

Silver chuckled, a sound like gravel rolling in a tin cup. “Oh, they’ll come, right enough. But let ‘em. We’ve got the ship, we’ve got the guns, and we’ve got the map. All we need is a bit of patience, lads. Treasure ain’t like a common wharf rat—it don’t scurry out just ‘cause you whistle for it.”

Israel Hands, leaning against the mast with a bottle in his fist, gave a drunken laugh. “Aye, and while we wait, the rum holds out, don’t it?” 

Some of the men chuckled, but others weren’t so easily swayed. A lean, sharp-faced sailor named Dick stepped forward. “Silver, you talk smooth as ever, but some of us ain’t forgot what happened to Alan and the others. They trusted you, and look where it got ‘em.”

A cold silence fell. Silver’s smile didn’t waver, but his fingers tightened around the hilt of his cutlass. “Alan was a good man,” he said slowly. “But he made his choice, same as we all do. This here’s a dangerous game, lads. If you can’t stomach it, there’s the shore—only don’t expect the sharks to be as forgiving as me.”

The threat hung in the air, unspoken but clear. Morgan spat on the deck. “Fine words from a man who changes sides quicker than the wind.”

Silver’s good humor vanished like a snuffed candle. In a flash, his cutlass was at Morgan’s throat, the point just pricking the skin. The crew froze. 

“You’ll mind your tongue, Tom,” Silver hissed, “or I’ll mind it for you. I’ve led you this far, haven’t I? Kept you fed, kept you alive. And when the time comes, I’ll lead you to Flint’s gold—if you’ve the spine to follow.”

Morgan didn’t flinch, but his breath came fast. After a long moment, Silver lowered the blade and stepped back, his grin returning as if nothing had happened. “Now then, lads! Let’s have no more of this squabbling. The tide turns at dawn, and we’ll make our move then. Until then, drink up, and dream of the fortune that’s nearly in our grasp!”

The men cheered halfheartedly, their unease not entirely dispelled. As they dispersed, Silver watched them go, his face unreadable. Young Jim Hawkins, hidden in the shadows of the companionway, felt a chill run down his spine. He had seen the real Long John Silver in that moment—not the jovial cook, not the cunning strategist, but the ruthless pirate who would slit a man’s throat as soon as look at him.

And Jim knew, with a sinking heart, that when the time came, Silver would do the same to any of them—even to him.

events.text_segment:
But here the long man with the yellow eyes struck in.
“Belay that talk, John Silver,” he said. “This crew has tipped you the black spot in full council, as in dooty bound; just you turn it over, as in dooty bound, and see what’s wrote there. Then you can talk.”
“Thanky, George,” replied the sea-cook. “You always was brisk for business, and has the rules by heart, George, as I’m pleased to see. Well, what is it, anyway? Ah! ‘Deposed’—that’s it, is it? Very pretty wrote, to be sure; like print, I swear. Your hand o’ write, George? Why, you was gettin’ quite a leadin’ man in this here crew. You’ll be cap’n next, I shouldn’t wonder. Just oblige me with that torch again, will you? This pipe don’t draw.”
“Come, now,” said George, “you don’t fool this crew no more. You’re a funny man, by your account; but you’re over now, and you’ll maybe step down off that barrel and help vote.”
“I thought you said you knowed the rules,” returned Silver contemptuously. “Leastways, if you don’t, I do; and I wait here—and I’m still your cap’n, mind—till you outs with your grievances and I reply; in the meantime, your black spot ain’t worth a biscuit. After that, we’ll see.”
“Oh,” replied George, “you don’t be under no kind of apprehension; we’re all square, we are. First, you’ve made a hash of this cruise—you’ll be a bold man to say no to that. Second, you let the enemy out o’ this here trap for nothing. Why did they want out? I dunno, but it’s pretty plain they wanted it. Third, you wouldn’t let us go at them upon the march. Oh, we see through you, John Silver; you want to play booty, that’s what’s wrong with you. And then, fourth, there’s this here boy.”
“Is that all?” asked Silver quietly.
“Enough, too,” retorted George. “We’ll all swing and sun-dry for your bungling.”

He then turned the blame on them, specifically Anderson, Hands, and George Merry, for crossing him, forcing his hand as the lawful captain, and giving him the black spot on the day they landed, thus starting the 'dance' leading to their current predicament.
He likened their situation to awaiting execution at Execution Dock in London.
Silver paused, and Jim observed that his words visibly affected George and his companions.
Wiping sweat from his brow after his vehement speech, Silver dismissed the first charge, expressing his disgust at having to speak to men with neither sense nor memory.
Morgan encouraged him to continue addressing the others.
Silver sarcastically referred to the others as a 'nice lot' and elaborated on how badly the cruise was bungled, emphasizing their proximity to the gallows.
He painted a vivid picture of them being hanged in chains, with seamen identifying their corpses.
He reiterated that their dire situation was thanks to Merry, Hands, Anderson, and other 'ruination fools'.

Well now, you all know what I wanted, and you all know if that had been done that we’d ’a been aboard the Hispaniola this night as ever was, every man of us alive, and fit, and full of good plum-duff, and the treasure in the hold of her, by thunder! Well, who crossed me? Who forced my hand, as was the lawful cap’n? Who tipped me the black spot the day we landed and began this dance? Ah, it’s a fine dance—I’m with you there—and looks mighty like a hornpipe in a rope’s end at Execution Dock by London town, it does. But who done it? Why, it was Anderson, and Hands, and you, George Merry! And you’re the last above board of that same meddling crew; and you have the Davy Jones’s insolence to up and stand for cap’n over me—you, that sank the lot of us! By the powers! But this tops the stiffest yarn to nothing.”
Silver paused, and I could see by the faces of George and his late comrades that these words had not been said in vain.
“That’s for number one,” cried the accused, wiping the sweat from his brow, for he had been talking with a vehemence that shook the house. “Why, I give you my word, I’m sick to speak to you. You’ve neither sense nor memory, and I leave it to fancy where your mothers was that let you come to sea. Sea! Gentlemen o’ fortune! I reckon tailors is your trade.”
“Go on, John,” said Morgan. “Speak up to the others.”
“Ah, the others!” returned John. “They’re a nice lot, ain’t they? You say this cruise is bungled. Ah! By gum, if you could understand how bad it’s bungled, you would see! We’re that near the gibbet that my neck’s stiff with thinking on it. You’ve seen ’em, maybe, hanged in chains, birds about ’em, seamen p’inting ’em out as they go down with the tide. ‘Who’s that?’ says one. ‘That! Why, that’s John Silver. I knowed him well,’ says another. And you can hear the chains a-jangle as you go about and reach for the other buoy. Now, that’s about where we are, every mother’s son of us, thanks to him, and Hands, and Anderson, and other ruination fools of you. And if you want to know about number four, and that boy, why, shiver my timbers, isn’t he a hostage? Are we a-going to waste a hostage? No, not us; he might be our last chance, and I shouldn’t wonder. Kill that boy? Not me, mates! And number three? Ah, well, there’s a deal to say to number three. Maybe you don’t count it nothing to have a real college doctor to see you every day—you, John, with your head broke—or you, George Merry, that had the ague shakes upon you not six hours agone, and has your eyes the colour of lemon peel to this same moment on the clock? And maybe, perhaps, you didn’t know there was a consort coming either? But there is, and not so long till then; and we’ll see who’ll be glad to have a hostage when it comes to that. And as for number two, and why I made a bargain—well, you came crawling on your knees to me to make it—on your knees you came, you was that downhearted—and you’d have starved too if I hadn’t—but that’s a trifle! You look there—that’s why!”

events.title: The Treasure Chart Revealed: Silver's Trump Card
detailed_summary: Silver threw a paper onto the floor, which Jim immediately identified as Captain Flint's treasure chart with the three red crosses, the same one he had found earlier.
Jim was completely mystified as to how Dr. Livesey could have given it to Silver.
The appearance of the chart was utterly unbelievable to the surviving mutineers.
They pounced on it like cats on a mouse, snatching it from one another with oaths, cries, and childish laughter, as if they were already handling the gold itself and sailing away safely with it.
One buccaneer confirmed its authenticity, recognizing Flint's mark 'J. F.' and a score with a clove hitch.
George Merry acknowledged its beauty but pragmatically questioned how they could escape with the treasure now that they had no ship.
Silver suddenly rose, supporting himself against the wall, and angrily warned George that one more disrespectful word would lead to a fight.
He retorted that George and the others should be the ones explaining how to get away, as they were responsible for losing the schooner through their interference.
Silver then insulted their intelligence, saying they lacked the ingenuity of a cockroach, but insisted George could and would speak respectfully.

events.text_segment:
And he cast down upon the floor a paper that I instantly recognized—none other than the chart on yellow paper, with the three red crosses, that I had found in the oilcloth at the bottom of the captain’s chest. Why the doctor had given it to him was more than I could fancy.
But if it were inexplicable to me, the appearance of the chart was incredible to the surviving mutineers. They leaped upon it like cats upon a mouse. It went from hand to hand, one tearing it from another; and by the oaths and the cries and the childish laughter with which they accompanied their examination, you would have thought, not only they were fingering the very gold, but were at sea with it, besides, in safety.
“Yes,” said one, “that’s Flint, sure enough. J. F., and a score below, with a clove hitch to it; so he done ever.”
“Mighty pretty,” said George. “But how are we to get away with it, and us no ship.”
Silver suddenly sprang up, and supporting himself with a hand against the wall: “Now I give you warning, George,” he cried. “One more word of your sauce, and I’ll call you down and fight you. How? Why, how do I know? You had ought to tell me that—you and the rest, that lost me my schooner, with your interference, burn you! But not you, you can’t; you hain’t got the invention of a cockroach. But civil you can speak, and shall, George Merry, you may lay to that.”

The sight of the chart sent a shiver down my spine. There it lay, the very same yellowed parchment that had once been hidden in the captain’s chest—the map to Flint’s treasure. The three blood-red crosses glared up at me, marking the spots where untold riches were buried. My hands trembled as I reached for it, but the stranger’s boot came down hard upon the paper, pinning it to the floor.  

“Aye, that’s it,” he growled, his voice rough as gravel. “The very chart that’s cost men their lives. You’ve no notion what you’ve stumbled upon, boy.”  

I swallowed hard, my mind racing. How had this man come by the map? Had he been one of Flint’s crew? His sunken eyes burned with a feverish light, and the scars upon his face told of battles fought in dark places.  

“This here’s my ticket to fortune,” he muttered, snatching up the chart. “And I’ll not let it slip through my fingers again.”

events.title: The Black Spot's Nature and Jim's Reflections on Silver's Game
detailed_summary: Silver tossed the black spot paper to Jim, calling it a curiosity.

Jim examined it: it was about the size of a crown piece. One side was blank, having been the last leaf of the Bible; the other contained verses from Revelation, including the striking words, 'Without are dogs and murderers.'
The printed side had been blackened with wood ash, which was already smudging Jim's fingers; on the blank side, the single word 'Depposed' had been written with the same ash.
Jim notes that, as he writes his account, the paper is still with him, but almost all traces of the writing have vanished, leaving only a faint scratch.
This concluded the night's dramatic events. After a round of drinks, everyone lay down to sleep.
Silver's only act of vengeance was to assign George Merry to sentinel duty, threatening him with death if he proved unfaithful.

Jim found it difficult to sleep, his mind filled with thoughts of the man he had killed that afternoon, his own dangerous situation, and, most significantly, the remarkable and complex game Silver was playing.
He recognized Silver's efforts to simultaneously keep the mutineers unified while desperately seeking any means to secure his own pardon and save his life.

Despite Silver's profound wickedness, Jim felt a sense of sorrow for him, contemplating the immense dangers surrounding him and the shameful execution that likely awaited him, even as Silver himself slept soundly and snored.

events.text_segment:
“Here, Jim—here’s a cur’osity for you,” said Silver, and he tossed me the paper.
It was around about the size of a crown piece. One side was blank, for it had been the last leaf; the other contained a verse or two of Revelation—these words among the rest, which struck sharply home upon my mind: “Without are dogs and murderers.” The printed side had been blackened with wood ash, which already began to come off and soil my fingers; on the blank side had been written with the same material the one word “Depposed.” I have that curiosity beside me at this moment, but not a trace of writing now remains beyond a single scratch, such as a man might make with his thumb-nail.
That was the end of the night’s business. Soon after, with a drink all round, we lay down to sleep, and the outside of Silver’s vengeance was to put George Merry up for sentinel and threaten him with death if he should prove unfaithful.
It was long ere I could close an eye, and heaven knows I had matter enough for thought in the man whom I had slain that afternoon, in my own most perilous position, and above all, in the remarkable game that I saw Silver now engaged upon—keeping the mutineers together with one hand and grasping with the other after every means, possible and impossible, to make his peace and save his miserable life. He himself slept peacefully and snored aloud, yet my heart was sore for him, wicked as he was, to think on the dark perils that environed and the shameful gibbet that awaited him.

“Here, Jim—here’s a cur’osity for you,” said Silver, and he tossed me the paper.  

I caught it, my hands trembling slightly, for I knew that anything Silver considered a "curiosity" was likely to be of great importance—or danger. The paper was worn at the edges, yellowed with age, and covered in a spidery scrawl. At first glance, it appeared to be a map, but not like any I had seen before. There were strange markings, crosses, and what looked like measurements, but no clear indication of land or sea.  

Silver watched me with his sharp, cunning eyes, a smirk playing on his lips. “Well, lad? What d’ye make of it?”  

I hesitated, unsure whether to admit my confusion or pretend I understood. “It’s... a map of some kind,” I ventured.  

“Aye, that it is,” he chuckled. “But not just any map. That there’s Flint’s own handiwork.”  

My breath caught at the name. Captain Flint—the most feared pirate of them all—was said to have buried treasures beyond imagining. If this was truly his map, then it could lead to untold riches—or death for those who sought them.  

“Where did you get this?” I asked, trying to keep my voice steady.  

Silver’s grin widened. “Ah, now that’s a tale for another time. But mark my words, Jim—this paper’s worth more than gold to the right man.”

detailed_summary: The inhabitants of the blockhouse, including Jim and a sentinel, are roused by Dr. Livesey's call from the nearby woods.
Jim feels a mixture of gladness at the doctor's arrival and profound shame due to his recent rebellious actions and the perilous situation they have led him into.
Dr. Livesey becomes visible through the morning vapor, indicating he had set out very early.
Silver immediately adopts a cheerful and welcoming tone, loudly greeting the doctor and assuring him that his patients are faring well.
With his characteristic demeanor, Silver informs Dr. Livesey about a "little stranger" among them, theatrically revealing Jim's presence.
Upon reaching the stockade and hearing Silver confirm Jim's presence, Dr. Livesey's voice noticeably changes, reflecting his surprise and concern.
The doctor pauses, clearly taken aback by the news, before stating that his medical duties must take precedence over personal matters.
He then enters the blockhouse, gives Jim a single, stern, and silent acknowledgment, and commences treating the injured pirates.

events.text_segment:
I was wakened—indeed, we were all wakened, for I could see even the sentinel shake himself together from where he had fallen against the door-post—by a clear, hearty voice hailing us from the margin of the wood:
“Block house, ahoy!” it cried. “Here’s the doctor.”
And the doctor it was. Although I was glad to hear the sound, yet my gladness was not without admixture. I remembered with confusion my insubordinate and stealthy conduct, and when I saw where it had brought me—among what companions and surrounded by what dangers—I felt ashamed to look him in the face.
He must have risen in the dark, for the day had hardly come; and when I ran to a loophole and looked out, I saw him standing, like Silver once before, up to the mid-leg in creeping vapour.
“You, doctor! Top o’ the morning to you, sir!” cried Silver, broad awake and beaming with good nature in a moment. “Bright and early, to be sure; and it’s the early bird, as the saying goes, that gets the rations. George, shake up your timbers, son, and help Dr. Livesey over the ship’s side. All a-doin’ well, your patients was—all well and merry.”
So he pattered on, standing on the hilltop with his crutch under his elbow and one hand upon the side of the log-house—quite the old John in voice, manner, and expression.
“We’ve quite a surprise for you too, sir,” he continued. “We’ve a little stranger here—he! he! A noo boarder and lodger, sir, and looking fit and taut as a fiddle; slep’ like a supercargo, he did, right alongside of John—stem to stem we was, all night.”
Dr. Livesey was by this time across the stockade and pretty near the cook, and I could hear the alteration in his voice as he said, “Not Jim?”
“The very same Jim as ever was,” says Silver.
The doctor stopped outright, although he did not speak, and it was some seconds before he seemed able to move on.
“Well, well,” he said at last, “duty first and pleasure afterwards, as you might have said yourself, Silver. Let us overhaul these patients of yours.”
A moment afterwards he had entered the block house and with one grim nod to me proceeded with his work among the sick.

"Ahoy there, the camp! Permission to come aboard?"  

The voice was bold and cheerful, ringing through the still morning air like a ship’s bell. I scrambled to my feet, rubbing the sleep from my eyes, and saw the others doing the same. Even the sentinel, who had been slumped against the door-post in a doze, jerked upright, blinking in confusion.  

A figure emerged from the edge of the wood—a tall, broad-shouldered man with a sun-browned face and a grin that seemed to split it in two. He wore a seaman’s jacket, though it was frayed at the edges, and his boots were caked with mud. In one hand, he carried a long staff, which he planted firmly in the ground as he surveyed our little camp.  

"Who goes there?" called the sentinel, fumbling for his musket.  

"Friend, not foe!" the stranger replied, raising his empty hands. "Name’s Ben Gunn, late of His Majesty’s Navy, and more recently—well, let’s just say I’ve been keeping myself busy on this island."  

At the mention of his name, Dr. Livesey stepped forward, his sharp eyes studying the man. "Ben Gunn? I’ve heard that name before."  

"Aye, Doctor, and I’ve heard yours," Ben said with a chuckle. "Seems we’ve both had our share of adventures since the *Hispaniola* dropped anchor here."  

The mention of the ship sent a ripple through our group. I felt my heart quicken. Was this man friend or another of Silver’s tricks? But there was something in his open face, his easy manner, that made me want to trust him.  

"Come forward then, Ben Gunn," the Doctor said at last. "But keep your hands where we can see them."  

Ben obeyed, his grin never fading. "Gladly, sir. And if you’ll hear me out, I’ve a tale to tell—and maybe a way off this cursed island for the lot of ye."

events.title: Dr. Livesey Treats the Mutineers with Stern Authority
characters: Mutineers (including one with bandaged head, George, Morgan, Dick)
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey shows no sign of fear, despite the inherent danger of being surrounded by the mutineers, and speaks to them as if on a routine medical visit.
His composed and professional manner appears to have a calming effect on the pirates, who treat him with a deference reminiscent of their former relationship on the ship.
He assesses a man with a bandaged head, remarking on his hardy constitution, then criticizes George's unhealthy appearance and inquires if he has taken his prescribed medicine.
Morgan, another mutineer, confirms that George did indeed take his medication.
Dr. Livesey pointedly identifies himself as the "mutineers' doctor" or, preferably, "prison doctor," asserting his commitment to prevent King George and the gallows from claiming any of his patients.
The pirates exchange uneasy looks but silently endure his pointed commentary.
When informed that a mutineer named Dick is unwell, the doctor examines him, humorously notes the appalling state of his tongue, and diagnoses another case of fever.

Morgan suggests the illness is a result of desecrating Bibles, but Dr. Livesey sharply counters that it stems from their own foolishness in choosing to camp in a toxic swamp, lacking basic understanding of hygiene and healthy environments.

He expresses his professional opinion that they are all likely to suffer greatly from malaria due to their ill-advised campsite, showing surprise at Silver's uncharacteristic lack of judgment regarding health matters.

After administering medicine to all the sick pirates, who accept his treatment with unexpected submissiveness, he declares his work for the day complete and then formally requests a private conversation with Jim.

events.text_segment:
He seemed under no apprehension, though he must have known that his life, among these treacherous demons, depended on a hair; and he rattled on to his patients as if he were paying an ordinary professional visit in a quiet English family. His manner, I suppose, reacted on the men, for they behaved to him as if nothing had occurred, as if he were still ship’s doctor and they still faithful hands before the mast.
“You’re doing well, my friend,” he said to the fellow with the bandaged head, “and if ever any person had a close shave, it was you; your head must be as hard as iron. Well, George, how goes it? You’re a pretty colour, certainly; why, your liver, man, is upside down. Did you take that medicine? Did he take that medicine, men?”
“Aye, aye, sir, he took it, sure enough,” returned Morgan.
“Because, you see, since I am mutineers’ doctor, or prison doctor as I prefer to call it,” says Doctor Livesey in his pleasantest way, “I make it a point of honour not to lose a man for King George (God bless him!) and the gallows.”
The rogues looked at each other but swallowed the home-thrust in silence.
“Dick don’t feel well, sir,” said one.
“Don’t he?” replied the doctor. “Well, step up here, Dick, and let me see your tongue. No, I should be surprised if he did! The man’s tongue is fit to frighten the French. Another fever.”
“Ah, there,” said Morgan, “that comed of sp’iling Bibles.”
“That comes—as you call it—of being arrant asses,” retorted the doctor, “and not having sense enough to know honest air from poison, and the dry land from a vile, pestiferous slough. I think it most probable—though of course it’s only an opinion—that you’ll all have the deuce to pay before you get that malaria out of your systems. Camp in a bog, would you? Silver, I’m surprised at you. You’re less of a fool than many, take you all round; but you don’t appear to me to have the rudiments of a notion of the rules of health.
“Well,” he added after he had dosed them round and they had taken his prescriptions, with really laughable humility, more like charity schoolchildren than blood-guilty mutineers and pirates—“well, that’s done for today. And now I should wish to have a talk with that boy, please.”

Dr. Livesey moved through the pirate camp with an air of calm authority, as though he were strolling through the lanes of his own village rather than the den of cutthroats. His manner was so composed, so utterly unshaken, that even the most hardened among them hesitated to raise a hand against him. He spoke to them as if they were merely troublesome patients in need of his care, his voice steady and his gaze unwavering.  

The pirates, for all their bluster and cruelty, were oddly subdued in his presence. Perhaps it was the sheer audacity of his indifference, or the quiet confidence that suggested he could not be cowed. Even Long John Silver, cunning as he was, watched the doctor with a mixture of wariness and grudging respect.  

“Now then,” Dr. Livesey said briskly, kneeling beside a groaning pirate with a festering wound, “this will need cleaning, unless you’d prefer to lose the leg.” His tone was matter-of-fact, as if discussing the weather rather than a man’s impending amputation. The pirate paled but nodded, and the doctor set to work without another word.  

All around him, the others muttered and shifted, their hands hovering near their weapons, yet none dared interrupt. There was something about the doctor—his unflinching professionalism, perhaps, or the simple fact that he treated them as men rather than monsters—that stayed their hands.  

When he had finished, he stood, wiping his hands on a cloth, and surveyed the group with the same detached interest he might give to a row of unruly schoolboys. “Any others in need of attention?” he asked, as though he were in a proper surgery rather than a den of thieves.  

For a moment, there was silence. Then, one by one, the pirates shuffled forward, their defiance crumbling under the weight of pain and the doctor’s unassailable composure. And so, amidst the treachery and violence, Dr. Livesey moved untouched—a man whose courage was as quiet as it was unbreakable.

events.title: Silver Negotiates Terms for Jim's Conversation with Dr. Livesey
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey casually gestures towards Jim while making his request for a private discussion.
George Merry, who is nearby recovering from unpleasant medicine, reacts angrily to the doctor's proposal, shouting "No!" and swearing.
Silver intervenes immediately and forcefully, striking a barrel and roaring for silence, his demeanor described as lion-like, effectively quelling the dissent.
Adopting his usual tone, Silver informs the doctor that he had anticipated such a request, acknowledging the doctor's known fondness for Jim.
He expresses the group's gratitude for the doctor's medical assistance, noting that the men trust him and willingly take his remedies.
Silver then proposes a compromise: Jim must give his word of honor, as a young gentleman, not to attempt an escape.
Jim readily gives the solemn promise required of him.
Silver outlines the arrangement: the doctor will wait outside the stockade, and Silver will bring Jim to the inside of the barrier, allowing them to converse through the wooden spars.
He concludes the exchange with a polite farewell, also sending respects to Squire Trelawney and Captain Smollett.

events.text_segment:
And he nodded his head in my direction carelessly.
George Merry was at the door, spitting and spluttering over some bad-tasted medicine; but at the first word of the doctor’s proposal he swung round with a deep flush and cried “No!” and swore.
Silver struck the barrel with his open hand.
“Si-lence!” he roared and looked about him positively like a lion. “Doctor,” he went on in his usual tones, “I was a-thinking of that, knowing as how you had a fancy for the boy. We’re all humbly grateful for your kindness, and as you see, puts faith in you and takes the drugs down like that much grog. And I take it I’ve found a way as’ll suit all. Hawkins, will you give me your word of honour as a young gentleman—for a young gentleman you are, although poor born—your word of honour not to slip your cable?”
I readily gave the pledge required.
“Then, doctor,” said Silver, “you just step outside o’ that stockade, and once you’re there I’ll bring the boy down on the inside, and I reckon you can yarn through the spars. Good day to you, sir, and all our dooties to the squire and Cap’n Smollett.”

And he nodded his head in my direction carelessly, as if I were of no more importance than a passing shadow. His cold, indifferent gaze barely lingered before turning away, leaving me standing there, clutching the old map in my trembling hands. The tavern buzzed with raucous laughter and the clinking of tankards, but in that moment, I felt utterly alone.  

That single dismissive gesture told me everything I needed to know—this man, this weathered sailor with his sun-scorched skin and missing fingers, had seen things I could scarcely imagine. He carried secrets like others carried coins, and he had no intention of sharing them with a boy like me.

events.title: Silver Quells Mutiny and Makes a Desperate Appeal to Dr. Livesey
detailed_summary: Once Dr. Livesey has departed from the blockhouse, the mutineers' restrained anger erupts, accusing Silver of duplicity, attempting to secure his own separate peace, and betraying their interests.
Jim observes that Silver's treachery seems blatant, yet Silver's dominant personality, further solidified by his recent triumph over the crew, allows him to manage their fury.

Silver scornfully calls his accusers fools, arguing that Jim's discussion with the doctor is essential, and questions if they can risk voiding their treaty precisely when they are about to search for the treasure.
He emphatically states that they will be the ones to break the treaty when the time is right, and until then, he intends to deceive and manipulate the doctor, even if it means extreme measures.
He then instructs them to build up the fire and, placing a hand on Jim's shoulder, guides him towards the stockade, warning him to proceed slowly to avoid raising any alarm among the men.

As they approach Dr. Livesey, Silver's demeanor shifts dramatically; he earnestly implores the doctor to take note of how he saved Jim's life, an act for which he was even temporarily deposed as leader.
He appeals for a 'good word' from the doctor and a glimmer of hope, stressing that not only his own life but Jim's too hangs in the balance, and asks the doctor to speak favorably on his behalf.
Silver, appearing gaunt and with a trembling voice, admits his profound fear of the gallows, despite asserting he is not a coward, and appeals to the doctor's recognized integrity and kindness.
He then retreats a short distance to be out of hearing range, settling on a tree stump from where he can observe both Jim with the doctor and his own men preparing breakfast, and begins to whistle.

The explosion of disapproval, which nothing but Silver’s black looks had restrained, broke out immediately the doctor had left the house. Silver was roundly accused of playing double—of trying to make a separate peace for himself, of sacrificing the interests of his accomplices and victims, and, in one word, of the identical, exact thing that he was doing. It seemed to me so obvious, in this case, that I could not imagine how he was to turn their anger. But he was twice the man the rest were, and his last night’s victory had given him a huge preponderance on their minds. He called them all the fools and dolts you can imagine, said it was necessary I should talk to the doctor, fluttered the chart in their faces, asked them if they could afford to break the treaty the very day they were bound a-treasure-hunting.
“No, by thunder!” he cried. “It’s us must break the treaty when the time comes; and till then I’ll gammon that doctor, if I have to ile his boots with brandy.”
And then he bade them get the fire lit, and stalked out upon his crutch, with his hand on my shoulder, leaving them in a disarray, and silenced by his volubility rather than convinced.
“Slow, lad, slow,” he said. “They might round upon us in a twinkle of an eye if we was seen to hurry.”
Very deliberately, then, did we advance across the sand to where the doctor awaited us on the other side of the stockade, and as soon as we were within easy speaking distance Silver stopped.
“You’ll make a note of this here also, doctor,” says he, “and the boy’ll tell you how I saved his life, and were deposed for it too, and you may lay to that. Doctor, when a man’s steering as near the wind as me—playing chuck-farthing with the last breath in his body, like—you wouldn’t think it too much, mayhap, to give him one good word? You’ll please bear in mind it’s not my life only now—it’s that boy’s into the bargain; and you’ll speak me fair, doctor, and give me a bit o’ hope to go on, for the sake of mercy.”
Silver was a changed man once he was out there and had his back to his friends and the block house; his cheeks seemed to have fallen in, his voice trembled; never was a soul more dead in earnest.
“Why, John, you’re not afraid?” asked Dr. Livesey.
“Doctor, I’m no coward; no, not I—not so much!” and he snapped his fingers. “If I was I wouldn’t say it. But I’ll own up fairly, I’ve the shakes upon me for the gallows. You’re a good man and a true; I never seen a better man! And you’ll not forget what I done good, not any more than you’ll forget the bad, I know. And I step aside—see here—and leave you and Jim alone. And you’ll put that down for me too, for it’s a long stretch, is that!”
So saying, he stepped back a little way, till he was out of earshot, and there sat down upon a tree-stump and began to whistle, spinning round now and again upon his seat so as to command a sight, sometimes of me and the doctor and sometimes of his unruly ruffians as they went to and fro in the sand between the fire—which they were busy rekindling—and the house, from which they brought forth pork and bread to make the breakfast.

The explosion of disapproval, which nothing but Silver’s black looks had restrained, broke out immediately the doctor had left the house. The men surged forward, their faces twisted with anger and fear, their voices rising in a clamor of curses and threats.  

“He’s sold us out!” cried one.  

“Aye, the doctor’s gone to warn the fort!” shouted another.  

“We’ll be hanged, every man jack of us!”  

Silver, though pale and sweating from his wound, stood firm. His one good eye flashed with authority as he raised his crutch and bellowed, “Silence!” The word cut through the uproar like a knife, and for a moment, the men hesitated.  

“Now, listen here, you fools,” Silver growled, his voice low but dangerous. “If you’d kept your heads instead of yammering like scared children, you’d see there’s no cause for panic. The doctor’s gone, aye—but what of it? He’s one man, and we’ve got the upper hand.”  

“Upper hand?” sneered Dick, his hands shaking. “He knows the island now! He’ll bring the soldiers down on us!”  

Silver’s lips curled into a cold smile. “And what if he does? We’ve got the stockade, haven’t we? We’ve got arms, and we’ve got the treasure. Or have you forgotten why we’re here?”  

The mention of the treasure quieted them somewhat, but mutters still passed among the crew.  

“But the map’s gone,” muttered one.  

“Aye, and Flint’s cipher with it,” added another.  

Silver’s face darkened. “The map’s gone, true enough, but I’ve got it all up here,” he said, tapping his temple. “Every landmark, every bearing. Flint himself couldn’t have drawn it clearer in my mind.”  

The men exchanged doubtful glances.  

“And what if you’re lying?” challenged George Merry, his eyes narrow with suspicion.  

Silver’s patience snapped. In a flash, he lunged forward, his crutch swinging like a club. Merry barely dodged in time, stumbling back as Silver snarled, “You question me again, George Merry, and I’ll send you after Flint! I’ve led you this far, haven’t I? Kept you fed, kept you alive when half the crew’s rotting in the ground! And this is my thanks?”  

The men shuffled uneasily. Silver’s fury was a terrifying thing, and none dared meet his eye now.  

At last, Israel Hands, who had been watching silently from the corner, spoke up. “Cap’n’s right,” he said gruffly. “We’ve got no choice but to trust him. Without him, we’re dead men.”  

Silver nodded, his breathing heavy. “That’s sense,” he said. “Now, here’s the plan. We move tonight—take the stockade by surprise. The doctor may have warned ‘em, but they won’t be expecting us so soon. We hit hard, we hit fast, and we take what’s ours.”  

A slow, grim determination settled over the men. The fear was still there, but now it was mixed with greed—the old, familiar hunger for gold.  

“Aye,” muttered one.  

“Aye,” echoed the rest.  

Silver grinned, though his eyes remained cold. “That’s more like it. Now, get your weapons ready. Tonight, we finish this.”  

And with that, the mutineers dispersed, their earlier panic replaced by a deadly resolve. But as Silver watched them go, his smile faded. He knew better than any of them just how precarious their position was—and how little room there was for error.  

The game was far from over.

events.title: Jim's Emotional Confession of Guilt and Fear of Torture
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey addresses Jim with a sorrowful tone, acknowledging that Jim is now facing the consequences of his earlier choices.

While stating he cannot find it in his heart to blame Jim, the doctor firmly asserts that Jim would never have dared to abandon them if Captain Smollett had been healthy, labeling his departure during the captain's illness as an act of cowardice.
Overwhelmed by this judgment, Jim begins to weep.
He implores the doctor to cease his reproaches, admitting he has already blamed himself extensively.
Jim concedes that his life is likely forfeit and that he owes his current survival to Silver's intervention.
He confesses that while he can face the prospect of death, which he feels he might deserve, his paramount fear is being subjected to torture by the pirates.

events.text_segment:
“So, Jim,” said the doctor sadly, “here you are. As you have brewed, so shall you drink, my boy. Heaven knows, I cannot find it in my heart to blame you, but this much I will say, be it kind or unkind: when Captain Smollett was well, you dared not have gone off; and when he was ill and couldn’t help it, by George, it was downright cowardly!”
I will own that I here began to weep. “Doctor,” I said, “you might spare me. I have blamed myself enough; my life’s forfeit anyway, and I should have been dead by now if Silver hadn’t stood for me; and doctor, believe this, I can die—and I dare say I deserve it—but what I fear is torture. If they come to torture me—”

events.title: Doctor's Escape Offer, Jim's Refusal, and Revelation of the Ship's Location
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey, his voice noticeably altered by Jim's distress over potential torture, interrupts him, declaring he cannot allow Jim to remain in such a dangerous situation.
He urgently suggests that Jim should immediately climb over the stockade so they can escape together.
Jim refuses the offer, reminding the doctor that he has given his solemn word to Silver not to attempt escape.
The doctor, clearly agitated, insists he will take full responsibility for breaking the promise, but Jim remains steadfast.
Jim argues that esteemed figures like the doctor, the squire, or the captain would not break their word, and he will not either, as Silver trusted him.

He explains that through a combination of fortune and bravery, he managed to recapture the ship, which is now concealed in North Inlet, resting on the southern beach, and would be high and dry at half tide.

“Jim,” the doctor interrupted, and his voice was quite changed, “Jim, I can’t have this. Whip over, and we’ll run for it.”
“Doctor,” said I, “I passed my word.”
“I know, I know,” he cried. “We can’t help that, Jim, now. I’ll take it on my shoulders, holus bolus, blame and shame, my boy; but stay here, I cannot let you. Jump! One jump, and you’re out, and we’ll run for it like antelopes.”
“No,” I replied; “you know right well you wouldn’t do the thing yourself—neither you nor squire nor captain; and no more will I. Silver trusted me; I passed my word, and back I go. But, doctor, you did not let me finish. If they come to torture me, I might let slip a word of where the ship is, for I got the ship, part by luck and part by risking, and she lies in North Inlet, on the southern beach, and just below high water. At half tide she must be high and dry.”
“The ship!” exclaimed the doctor.

“Sir,” said Silver, “as between man and man, that’s too much and too little. What you’re after, why you left the block house, why you given me that there chart, I don’t know, now, do I? And yet I done your bidding with my eyes shut and never a word of hope! But no, this here’s too much. If you won’t tell me what you mean plain out, just say so and I’ll leave the helm.”
“No,” said the doctor musingly; “I’ve no right to say more; it’s not my secret, you see, Silver, or, I give you my word, I’d tell it you. But I’ll go as far with you as I dare go, and a step beyond, for I’ll have my wig sorted by the captain or I’m mistaken! And first, I’ll give you a bit of hope; Silver, if we both get alive out of this wolf-trap, I’ll do my best to save you, short of perjury.”
Silver’s face was radiant. “You couldn’t say more, I’m sure, sir, not if you was my mother,” he cried.
“Well, that’s my first concession,” added the doctor. “My second is a piece of advice: keep the boy close beside you, and when you need help, halloo. I’m off to seek it for you, and that itself will show you if I speak at random. Good-bye, Jim.”
And Dr. Livesey shook hands with me through the stockade, nodded to Silver, and set off at a brisk pace into the wood.

events.title: Breakfast and Observations on Pirate Recklessness
detailed_summary: The group is summoned for breakfast, which consists of biscuits and fried preserved meat, cooked over an excessively large and hot fire.
Jim observes the pirates' profound wastefulness, noting they prepared roughly three times more food than could be consumed, with the excess carelessly thrown into the flames.

He reflects on their improvident, hand-to-mouth lifestyle and sleeping on watch, concluding that despite their boldness for brief engagements, they are entirely unsuited for any prolonged or organized campaign.
Jim is particularly surprised that Silver, typically astute and disciplined, offers no criticism of their recklessness, even as he eats with Captain Flint, his parrot, perched on his shoulder.

events.text_segment:
Just then a man hailed us from the fire that breakfast was ready, and we were soon seated here and there about the sand over biscuit and fried junk. They had lit a fire fit to roast an ox, and it was now grown so hot that they could only approach it from the windward, and even there not without precaution. In the same wasteful spirit, they had cooked, I suppose, three times more than we could eat; and one of them, with an empty laugh, threw what was left into the fire, which blazed and roared again over this unusual fuel. I never in my life saw men so careless of the morrow; hand to mouth is the only word that can describe their way of doing; and what with wasted food and sleeping sentries, though they were bold enough for a brush and be done with it, I could see their entire unfitness for anything like a prolonged campaign.
Even Silver, eating away, with Captain Flint upon his shoulder, had not a word of blame for their recklessness. And this the more surprised me, for I thought he had never shown himself so cunning as he did then.

events.title: Jim's Deepening Despair and Multifaceted Anxiety
detailed_summary: While Silver's speech lifts the pirates' spirits, Jim feels profoundly dejected.

He recognizes that if Silver's outlined scheme proves successful, the already duplicitous pirate would not hesitate to betray the doctor's party again, preferring wealth and freedom with the pirates over the mere escape from hanging offered by his agreement with Dr. Livesey.

Jim considers the grave danger he would face even if Silver were forced to remain loyal to Dr. Livesey, envisioning a desperate struggle for survival—a crippled man and a boy against five able seamen—should the pirates' suspicions about Silver's allegiance turn to certainty.

His distress is amplified by the unresolved mysteries surrounding his friends' actions: their desertion of the stockade, the surrender of the treasure chart, and Dr. Livesey's cryptic warning to Silver about expecting trouble upon finding the treasure.
These combined anxieties leave Jim with no appetite and a heavy heart as he embarks on the treasure hunt with his captors.

It was no wonder the men were in a good humour now. For my part, I was horribly cast down. Should the scheme he had now sketched prove feasible, Silver, already doubly a traitor, would not hesitate to adopt it. He had still a foot in either camp, and there was no doubt he would prefer wealth and freedom with the pirates to a bare escape from hanging, which was the best he had to hope on our side.
Nay, and even if things so fell out that he was forced to keep his faith with Dr. Livesey, even then what danger lay before us! What a moment that would be when the suspicions of his followers turned to certainty and he and I should have to fight for dear life—he a cripple and I a boy—against five strong and active seamen!
Add to this double apprehension the mystery that still hung over the behaviour of my friends, their unexplained desertion of the stockade, their inexplicable cession of the chart, or harder still to understand, the doctor’s last warning to Silver, “Look out for squalls when you find it,” and you will readily believe how little taste I found in my breakfast and with how uneasy a heart I set forth behind my captors on the quest for treasure.

events.title: The Treasure Hunting Expedition Sets Out
detailed_summary: The treasure-seeking party presents an odd appearance, dressed in dirty sailor attire and, with the exception of Jim, heavily armed.
Silver is particularly well-equipped with two slung guns, a cutlass, and pistols in his coat pockets, while his parrot, Captain Flint, sits on his shoulder chattering.
Jim is led by a rope tied around his waist, the end held by Silver, making Jim feel like a 'dancing bear'.
Other pirates are laden with tools such as picks and shovels, which were their first priority brought ashore, and provisions like pork, bread, and brandy.

Jim observes that all their supplies originate from the loyal party's stock, confirming Silver's earlier statement about striking a bargain with the doctor; without it, the mutineers would have faced severe shortages.
The entire group, including a man with a head injury who should have been resting, proceeds to the beach where two gigs, showing signs of the pirates' previous drunken neglect, await them.
For safety, both boats are used, and the party divides itself between them to set off across the anchorage.

events.text_segment:
We made a curious figure, had anyone been there to see us—all in soiled sailor clothes and all but me armed to the teeth. Silver had two guns slung about him—one before and one behind—besides the great cutlass at his waist and a pistol in each pocket of his square-tailed coat. To complete his strange appearance, Captain Flint sat perched upon his shoulder and gabbling odds and ends of purposeless sea-talk. I had a line about my waist and followed obediently after the sea-cook, who held the loose end of the rope, now in his free hand, now between his powerful teeth. For all the world, I was led like a dancing bear.
The other men were variously burthened, some carrying picks and shovels—for that had been the very first necessary they brought ashore from the Hispaniola—others laden with pork, bread, and brandy for the midday meal. All the stores, I observed, came from our stock, and I could see the truth of Silver’s words the night before. Had he not struck a bargain with the doctor, he and his mutineers, deserted by the ship, must have been driven to subsist on clear water and the proceeds of their hunting. Water would have been little to their taste; a sailor is not usually a good shot; and besides all that, when they were so short of eatables, it was not likely they would be very flush of powder.
Well, thus equipped, we all set out—even the fellow with the broken head, who should certainly have kept in shadow—and straggled, one after another, to the beach, where the two gigs awaited us. Even these bore trace of the drunken folly of the pirates, one in a broken thwart, and both in their muddy and unbailed condition. Both were to be carried along with us for the sake of safety; and so, with our numbers divided between them, we set forth upon the bosom of the anchorage.

We made a curious figure, had anyone been there to see us—all in soiled sailor clothes and all but me armed to the teeth. Silver, with his wooden leg swinging awkwardly, carried a musket slung over his shoulder and a cutlass at his belt. His face was grim, yet his eyes darted about with a restless cunning. Behind him, the pirates shuffled in a ragged line, their weapons glinting in the sunlight—pistols, knives, and boarding axes bristling from their belts.  

I, poor Jim Hawkins, walked unarmed among them, feeling every bit the captive though none had laid a hand on me. My heart pounded as I stole glances at their rough faces, each man marked by years of lawless living. Israel Hands, his scarred visage twisted in a sneer, kept close to Silver, while George Merry muttered darkly under his breath.  

The air was thick with tension, for though they followed Silver now, I knew their loyalty was as thin as the edge of a knife. One wrong word, one misstep, and the fragile truce would shatter. The treasure—that cursed, glittering hoard—was all that held them together.  

As we trudged up the wooded slope, the trees whispered secrets of the island, and I wondered if we would ever leave it alive. Silver’s parrot, Captain Flint, perched on his shoulder, let out a sudden, mocking cry: *"Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!"* The men started, hands flying to their weapons, and Silver’s voice cut through the silence like steel.  

"Steady, lads," he growled. "The boy’s with us, and the treasure’s ahead. No need for trouble—yet."  

But trouble, I knew, was never far behind.

events.title: Navigating by Chart and Ascending to the Plateau
detailed_summary: While rowing across the anchorage, the pirates discuss the treasure map, recognizing that the large red cross marking the treasure's location is too imprecise to be a definitive guide.
The chart's instructions refer to specific landmarks: 'Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.'
The main landmark is a 'tall tree,' but the nearby plateau is densely covered with pine trees of various heights, making identification from their current position challenging.
Despite the ambiguity, most pirates aboard the boats eagerly select their own candidate for the 'tall tree,' though Long John Silver advises them to wait until they are on site.
Following Silver's direction to row slowly to conserve energy, they eventually land at the mouth of the island's second river, which flows down from the Spy-glass hill.
Turning left, they begin to climb the slope towards the plateau, initially facing difficult terrain with heavy, miry ground and dense, marsh-like vegetation.

As they progress, the ground becomes steeper and stonier, and the forest more open, leading them into a more pleasant area of the island characterized by fragrant broom, flowering shrubs, green nutmeg trees, and tall pines.
The fresh, stirring air under the bright sunlight provides a welcome sensory refreshment.

events.text_segment:
As we pulled over, there was some discussion on the chart. The red cross was, of course, far too large to be a guide; and the terms of the note on the back, as you will hear, admitted of some ambiguity. They ran, the reader may remember, thus: Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.
A tall tree was thus the principal mark. Now, right before us the anchorage was bounded by a plateau from two to three hundred feet high, adjoining on the north the sloping southern shoulder of the Spy-glass and rising again towards the south into the rough, cliffy eminence called the Mizzenmast Hill. The top of the plateau was dotted thickly with pine-trees of varying height. Every here and there, one of a different species rose forty or fifty feet clear above its neighbours, and which of these was the particular “tall tree” of Captain Flint could only be decided on the spot, and by the readings of the compass.
Yet, although that was the case, every man on board the boats had picked a favourite of his own ere we were half-way over, Long John alone shrugging his shoulders and bidding them wait till they were there.
We pulled easily, by Silver’s directions, not to weary the hands prematurely, and after quite a long passage, landed at the mouth of the second river—that which runs down a woody cleft of the Spy-glass. Thence, bending to our left, we began to ascend the slope towards the plateau.
At the first outset, heavy, miry ground and a matted, marish vegetation greatly delayed our progress; but by little and little the hill began to steepen and become stony under foot, and the wood to change its character and to grow in a more open order. It was, indeed, a most pleasant portion of the island that we were now approaching. A heavy-scented broom and many flowering shrubs had almost taken the place of grass. Thickets of green nutmeg-trees were dotted here and there with the red columns and the broad shadow of the pines; and the first mingled their spice with the aroma of the others. The air, besides, was fresh and stirring, and this, under the sheer sunbeams, was a wonderful refreshment to our senses.

As we pulled over, there was some discussion on the chart. Captain Smollett, with his usual stern expression, spread the worn parchment across the table, its edges frayed from years of handling. The ink had faded in places, but the markings were still clear enough—the jagged coastline, the crosses marking possible treasure, and the ominous red "X" that had drawn us all into this perilous adventure.  

Squire Trelawney leaned in eagerly, his face flushed with excitement. "There it is, gentlemen! The very spot Flint marked his spoils. A fortune beyond imagining!" His voice trembled with greed, and I couldn't help but notice how his fingers twitched as if already grasping gold.  

Dr. Livesey, ever the voice of reason, traced a line along the chart with his finger. "Aye, but we mustn't forget the dangers. The island is uncharted beyond this point, and Flint was not a man to leave his treasure unguarded." His sharp eyes flicked toward me, as if silently warning me to stay alert.  

Long John Silver, leaning on his crutch, gave a low chuckle. "Dangers, aye, but what's a bit o' risk when there's gold to be had?" His smile was easy, but his dark eyes held something calculating. I had learned by now to distrust that look.  

The captain folded his arms. "We'll proceed with caution. No reckless digging, no splitting the crew until we know the lay of the land." His tone brooked no argument, and even the squire nodded reluctantly.  

As the men dispersed, I lingered, staring at the chart. That red "X" seemed to pulse like a heartbeat, calling to me. Was it truly fortune waiting there—or something far worse? The wind howled outside, and for the first time, I wondered if we were being watched.  

Perhaps the real treasure was not gold, but survival itself.

events.title: Ominous Discovery of an Artificially Placed Skeleton
detailed_summary: The pirates fan out across the terrain, moving boisterously, shouting and leaping as they advance.
Silver and Jim, with Jim still tethered, follow more slowly in the center, some distance behind the main group; Jim occasionally has to assist Silver to prevent him from falling on the loose gravel.
After covering about half a mile and nearing the top of the plateau, a pirate on the far left flank suddenly begins to shout repeatedly, as if in terror.
The other pirates, including Morgan who quickly dismisses the idea that the treasure itself has been found, rush towards the source of the cries.
Upon reaching the spot, they discover a human skeleton at the foot of a large pine tree, entangled in a green creeper which has even dislodged some of the smaller bones.
Jim observes that this sight sends a momentary chill through everyone present.
George Merry, venturing closer to examine the tattered clothing, identifies the remains as those of a seaman by the quality of the cloth.
Silver concurs, dryly noting one wouldn't expect to find a bishop there, but immediately questions the unnatural way the bones are arranged.

A more careful examination reveals that, despite some disturbance likely from scavengers or plant growth, the skeleton lies perfectly straight, with its feet pointing one way and its hands extended above its head, pointing in the exact opposite direction, like a diver.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The party spread itself abroad, in a fan shape, shouting and leaping to and fro.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Indeed, on a second glance, it seemed impossible to fancy that the body was in a natural position. But for some disarray (the work, perhaps, of the birds that had fed upon him or of the slow-growing creeper that had gradually enveloped his remains) the man lay perfectly straight—his feet pointing in one direction, his hands, raised above his head like a diver’s, pointing directly in the opposite.

events.text_segment:
The party spread itself abroad, in a fan shape, shouting and leaping to and fro. About the centre, and a good way behind the rest, Silver and I followed—I tethered by my rope, he ploughing, with deep pants, among the sliding gravel. From time to time, indeed, I had to lend him a hand, or he must have missed his footing and fallen backward down the hill.
We had thus proceeded for about half a mile and were approaching the brow of the plateau when the man upon the farthest left began to cry aloud, as if in terror. Shout after shout came from him, and the others began to run in his direction.
“He can’t ’a found the treasure,” said old Morgan, hurrying past us from the right, “for that’s clean a-top.”
Indeed, as we found when we also reached the spot, it was something very different. At the foot of a pretty big pine and involved in a green creeper, which had even partly lifted some of the smaller bones, a human skeleton lay, with a few shreds of clothing, on the ground. I believe a chill struck for a moment to every heart.
“He was a seaman,” said George Merry, who, bolder than the rest, had gone up close and was examining the rags of clothing. “Leastways, this is good sea-cloth.”

Silver pushed his way to the front, his one good eye gleaming. "Stand back, ye dogs!" he snarled. With a heave, he flung open the lid—only to reveal a handful of moldy coins and a rusted dagger.

"Blast it all!" shouted one, kicking the chest in frustration.

Another pirate adds to the chilling atmosphere by describing Flint's last moments: raging, demanding rum, and singing 'Fifteen Men,' a song that has haunted him ever since.

events.text_segment:
“I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver. “Here’s the compass; there’s the tip-top p’int o’ Skeleton Island, stickin’ out like a tooth. Just take a bearing, will you, along the line of them bones.”
It was done. The body pointed straight in the direction of the island, and the compass read duly E.S.E. and by E.
“I thought so,” cried the cook; “this here is a p’inter. Right up there is our line for the Pole Star and the jolly dollars. But, by thunder! If it don’t make me cold inside to think of Flint. This is one of his jokes, and no mistake. Him and these six was alone here; he killed ’em, every man; and this one he hauled here and laid down by compass, shiver my timbers! They’re long bones, and the hair’s been yellow. Aye, that would be Allardyce. You mind Allardyce, Tom Morgan?”
“Aye, aye,” returned Morgan; “I mind him; he owed me money, he did, and took my knife ashore with him.”
“Speaking of knives,” said another, “why don’t we find his’n lying round? Flint warn’t the man to pick a seaman’s pocket; and the birds, I guess, would leave it be.”
“By the powers, and that’s true!” cried Silver.
“There ain’t a thing left here,” said Merry, still feeling round among the bones; “not a copper doit nor a baccy box. It don’t look nat’ral to me.”
“No, by gum, it don’t,” agreed Silver; “not nat’ral, nor not nice, says you. Great guns! Messmates, but if Flint was living, this would be a hot spot for you and me. Six they were, and six are we; and bones is what they are now.”
“I saw him dead with these here deadlights,” said Morgan. “Billy took me in. There he laid, with penny-pieces on his eyes.”
“Dead—aye, sure enough he’s dead and gone below,” said the fellow with the bandage; “but if ever sperrit walked, it would be Flint’s. Dear heart, but he died bad, did Flint!”
“Aye, that he did,” observed another; “now he raged, and now he hollered for the rum, and now he sang. ‘Fifteen Men’ were his only song, mates; and I tell you true, I never rightly liked to hear it since. It was main hot, and the windy was open, and I hear that old song comin’ out as clear as clear—and the death-haul on the man already.”
“Come, come,” said Silver; “stow this talk. He’s dead, and he don’t walk, that I know; leastways, he won’t walk by day, and you may lay to that. Care killed a cat. Fetch ahead for the doubloons.”
We started, certainly; but in spite of the hot sun and the staring daylight, the pirates no longer ran separate and shouting through the wood, but kept side by side and spoke with bated breath. The terror of the dead buccaneer had fallen on their spirits.

“I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver, leaning back against the barrel with a sly grin. His one good eye gleamed in the dim light of the Hispaniola’s cabin, while the other, lost long ago to some forgotten skirmish, remained a hollow reminder of his treacherous past. The crew shifted uneasily, their faces a mix of curiosity and suspicion. They knew all too well that when Long John Silver had a notion, it usually meant trouble—or treasure.  

“And what might that be, Captain?” asked Dick, the youngest of the lot, his voice trembling slightly.  

Silver chuckled, the sound like gravel rolling in a tin cup. “Why, it’s about that there map, lads. The one the doctor and the squire are so keen on keeping to themselves.” He tapped his temple knowingly. “I’ve been turning it over in my mind, and it strikes me that Flint’s treasure ain’t buried where they think it is.”  

A murmur rippled through the men. Israel Hands, his face scarred and grim, narrowed his eyes. “You calling Flint a liar?”  

“Not at all, not at all,” Silver said smoothly, raising a placating hand. “But even the cleverest of men can be mistaken. And Flint—God rest his wicked soul—was a man who loved his games. What if he left a false trail? What if the real treasure’s waiting somewhere else, just laughing at us while we dig up empty sand?”  

The crew exchanged glances. The idea was dangerous—mutinous, even. But the promise of gold had a way of loosening men’s morals.  

“So what’s your plan, Silver?” growled George Merry, his fingers twitching near his cutlass.  

Silver’s grin widened. “Why, we let the squire and his lot lead us to where they think the treasure is. Let them wear themselves out digging. And when they’re good and tired, we’ll take the ship and sail to the real spot.”  

“And how d’you know where that is?” demanded Hands.  

Silver leaned forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. “Because, mates, I’ve got a little secret of my own. Flint told me things—things he never wrote down on any map.”  

The men fell silent, the weight of his words hanging in the air. Even the creaking of the ship’s timbers seemed to pause.  

“You’re asking us to betray the captain,” muttered one of the crew.  

Silver’s expression darkened. “No, lad. I’m asking you to be rich.”  

And with that, the die was cast. The men nodded, one by one, their greed outweighing their fear. Silver leaned back again, satisfied. His notion had taken root. Now all that remained was to see it through—to outwit the squire, the doctor, and young Jim Hawkins himself.  

For in the end, Long John Silver knew one truth above all others: in the hunt for treasure, it wasn’t the strongest or the bravest who won. It was the cleverest. And he intended to prove it.

Partly from the damping influence of this alarm, partly to rest Silver and the sick folk, the whole party sat down as soon as they had gained the brow of the ascent.
The plateau being somewhat tilted towards the west, this spot on which we had paused commanded a wide prospect on either hand. Before us, over the tree-tops, we beheld the Cape of the Woods fringed with surf; behind, we not only looked down upon the anchorage and Skeleton Island, but saw—clear across the spit and the eastern lowlands—a great field of open sea upon the east. Sheer above us rose the Spy-glass, here dotted with single pines, there black with precipices. There was no sound but that of the distant breakers, mounting from all round, and the chirp of countless insects in the brush. Not a man, not a sail, upon the sea; the very largeness of the view increased the sense of solitude.
Silver, as he sat, took certain bearings with his compass.
“There are three ‘tall trees,’” said he, “about in the right line from Skeleton Island. ‘Spy-glass shoulder,’ I take it, means that lower p’int there. It’s child’s play to find the stuff now. I’ve half a mind to dine first.”
“I don’t feel sharp,” growled Morgan. “Thinkin’ o’ Flint—I think it were—as done me.”
“Ah, well, my son, you praise your stars he’s dead,” said Silver.
“He were an ugly devil,” cried a third pirate with a shudder; “that blue in the face too!”
“That was how the rum took him,” added Merry. “Blue! Well, I reckon he was blue. That’s a true word.”

The buccaneers remained rooted to the ground, their eyes starting from their heads. Long after the voice had died away they still stared in silence, dreadfully, before them.
“That fixes it!” gasped one. “Let’s go.”
“They was his last words,” moaned Morgan, “his last words above board.”
Dick had his Bible out and was praying volubly. He had been well brought up, had Dick, before he came to sea and fell among bad companions.

This argument seemed weak enough to me. But you can never tell what will affect the superstitious, and to my wonder, George Merry was greatly relieved.
“Well, that’s so,” he said. “You’ve a head upon your shoulders, John, and no mistake. ’Bout ship, mates! This here crew is on a wrong tack, I do believe. And come to think on it, it was like Flint’s voice, I grant you, but not just so clear-away like it, after all. It was liker somebody else’s voice now—it was liker—”
“By the powers, Ben Gunn!” roared Silver.
“Aye, and so it were,” cried Morgan, springing on his knees. “Ben Gunn it were!”
“It don’t make much odds, do it, now?” asked Dick. “Ben Gunn’s not here in the body any more’n Flint.”
But the older hands greeted this remark with scorn.
“Why, nobody minds Ben Gunn,” cried Merry; “dead or alive, nobody minds him.”
It was extraordinary how their spirits had returned and how the natural colour had revived in their faces. Soon they were chatting together, with intervals of listening; and not long after, hearing no further sound, they shouldered the tools and set forth again, Merry walking first with Silver’s compass to keep them on the right line with Skeleton Island. He had said the truth: dead or alive, nobody minded Ben Gunn.

events.text_segment:
Dick alone still held his Bible, and looked around him as he went, with fearful glances; but he found no sympathy, and Silver even joked him on his precautions.
“I told you,” said he—“I told you you had sp’iled your Bible. If it ain’t no good to swear by, what do you suppose a sperrit would give for it? Not that!” and he snapped his big fingers, halting a moment on his crutch.
But Dick was not to be comforted; indeed, it was soon plain to me that the lad was falling sick; hastened by heat, exhaustion, and the shock of his alarm, the fever, predicted by Dr. Livesey, was evidently growing swiftly higher.
It was fine open walking here, upon the summit; our way lay a little downhill, for, as I have said, the plateau tilted towards the west. The pines, great and small, grew wide apart; and even between the clumps of nutmeg and azalea, wide open spaces baked in the hot sunshine. Striking, as we did, pretty near north-west across the island, we drew, on the one hand, ever nearer under the shoulders of the Spy-glass, and on the other, looked ever wider over that western bay where I had once tossed and trembled in the coracle.
The first of the tall trees was reached, and by the bearings proved the wrong one. So with the second.

events.title: The True Landmark Tree and the Overwhelming Grip of Gold Fever
detailed_summary: The third tree they found was a colossal specimen, soaring almost two hundred feet high with a massive red trunk and a broad shadow, making it a prominent landmark visible from both east and west coasts.
However, it was not the tree's size that captivated the pirates, but the knowledge that seven hundred thousand pounds in gold was supposedly buried beneath its shadow.
As they drew closer to this tree, the intense desire for the money completely eclipsed their earlier fears.
Their eyes began to burn with anticipation, their steps became quicker and lighter, and their entire focus was consumed by the immense fortune awaiting them.
Silver, hobbling on his crutch, grunted with effort, his nostrils flared, and he cursed like a madman when flies landed on his heated face.
He violently tugged the rope securing Jim Hawkins to him and frequently cast deadly glares at the boy.

Jim clearly perceived that Silver made no effort to conceal his intentions: in the immediate proximity of the gold, all promises and warnings were forgotten, and Silver fully intended to seize the treasure, retake the Hispaniola by night, eliminate every honest person on the island, and sail away laden with riches and crimes as originally planned.

The third rose nearly two hundred feet into the air above a clump of underwood—a giant of a vegetable, with a red column as big as a cottage, and a wide shadow around in which a company could have manoeuvred. It was conspicuous far to sea both on the east and west and might have been entered as a sailing mark upon the chart.
But it was not its size that now impressed my companions; it was the knowledge that seven hundred thousand pounds in gold lay somewhere buried below its spreading shadow. The thought of the money, as they drew nearer, swallowed up their previous terrors. Their eyes burned in their heads; their feet grew speedier and lighter; their whole soul was bound up in that fortune, that whole lifetime of extravagance and pleasure, that lay waiting there for each of them.
Silver hobbled, grunting, on his crutch; his nostrils stood out and quivered; he cursed like a madman when the flies settled on his hot and shiny countenance; he plucked furiously at the line that held me to him and from time to time turned his eyes upon me with a deadly look. Certainly he took no pains to hide his thoughts, and certainly I read them like print.

events.text_segment:
There never was such an overturn in this world. Each of these six men was as though he had been struck. But with Silver the blow passed almost instantly. Every thought of his soul had been set full-stretch, like a racer, on that money; well, he was brought up, in a single second, dead; and he kept his head, found his temper, and changed his plan before the others had had time to realize the disappointment.
“Jim,” he whispered, “take that, and stand by for trouble.”
And he passed me a double-barrelled pistol.
At the same time, he began quietly moving northward, and in a few steps had put the hollow between us two and the other five. Then he looked at me and nodded, as much as to say, “Here is a narrow corner,” as, indeed, I thought it was. His looks were not quite friendly, and I was so revolted at these constant changes that I could not forbear whispering, “So you’ve changed sides again.”
There was no time left for him to answer in. The buccaneers, with oaths and cries, began to leap, one after another, into the pit and to dig with their fingers, throwing the boards aside as they did so. Morgan found a piece of gold. He held it up with a perfect spout of oaths. It was a two-guinea piece, and it went from hand to hand among them for a quarter of a minute.
“Two guineas!” roared Merry, shaking it at Silver. “That’s your seven hundred thousand pounds, is it? You’re the man for bargains, ain’t you? You’re him that never bungled nothing, you wooden-headed lubber!”
“Dig away, boys,” said Silver with the coolest insolence; “you’ll find some pig-nuts and I shouldn’t wonder.”
“Pig-nuts!” repeated Merry, in a scream. “Mates, do you hear that? I tell you now, that man there knew it all along. Look in the face of him and you’ll see it wrote there.”
“Ah, Merry,” remarked Silver, “standing for cap’n again? You’re a pushing lad, to be sure.”
But this time everyone was entirely in Merry’s favour. They began to scramble out of the excavation, darting furious glances behind them. One thing I observed, which looked well for us: they all got out upon the opposite side from Silver.

Well, there we stood, two on one side, five on the other, the pit between us, and nobody screwed up high enough to offer the first blow. Silver never moved; he watched them, very upright on his crutch, and looked as cool as ever I saw him. He was brave, and no mistake.

Merry tumbled head foremost into the excavation; the man with the bandage spun round like a teetotum and fell all his length upon his side, where he lay dead, but still twitching; and the other three turned and ran for it with all their might.
Before you could wink, Long John had fired two barrels of a pistol into the struggling Merry, and as the man rolled up his eyes at him in the last agony, “George,” said he, “I reckon I settled you.”
At the same moment, the doctor, Gray, and Ben Gunn joined us, with smoking muskets, from among the nutmeg-trees.

“Forward!” cried the doctor. “Double quick, my lads. We must head ’em off the boats.”
And we set off at a great pace, sometimes plunging through the bushes to the chest.
I tell you, but Silver was anxious to keep up with us. The work that man went through, leaping on his crutch till the muscles of his chest were fit to burst, was work no sound man ever equalled; and so thinks the doctor. As it was, he was already thirty yards behind us and on the verge of strangling when we reached the brow of the slope.
“Doctor,” he hailed, “see there! No hurry!”
Sure enough there was no hurry. In a more open part of the plateau, we could see the three survivors still running in the same direction as they had started, right for Mizzenmast Hill. We were already between them and the boats; and so we four sat down to breathe, while Long John, mopping his face, came slowly up with us.
“Thank ye kindly, doctor,” says he. “You came in in about the nick, I guess, for me and Hawkins. And so it’s you, Ben Gunn!” he added. “Well, you’re a nice one, to be sure.”
“I’m Ben Gunn, I am,” replied the maroon, wriggling like an eel in his embarrassment. “And,” he added, after a long pause, “how do, Mr. Silver? Pretty well, I thank ye, says you.”
“Ben, Ben,” murmured Silver, “to think as you’ve done me!”
